context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Before you proceed, if I may have your ear Mr. Clagett, I overlooked announcing at the outset that Mr. Justice Marshall reserves the right to participate in this case on the basis of records and recording of the argument.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

The Government submits that the law in governing this case is clear and leaves in our opinion no room for doubt that United States has the paramount right to the natural resources of the Outer Continental Shelf under --
There was dictum in prior cases.

They would have suggested perhaps state ownership of close in waters but only dictums, the California court pointed out as there was those statements that were too broad, the case of the courts in those cases were dealing usually with inland waters.
And so that there was no law which California suddenly overturned.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Solicitor General, what do you make of Justice Frankfurter's comment in the Texas case that in California, the Court did amend the proposed decree submitted by the Government to strike out the terms of proprietorship?
I've been puzzling over that Mr. Justice Rehnquist because the decree gives dominion in full control and so forth that I think later decrees give proprietorship in this state cases.
And I'm not quite clear what the significance of that striking of those words is.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of No. 35 Original, United States against Maine and others will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This is in the original action brought by the United States against 13 of the states with coast lines on the Atlantic Ocean.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The issue is the ownership of the seabed of the continental shelf lying outside the three mile limit within which the seabed has been granted to the states by the Submerged Lands Act.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We think that the case indeed is controlled by our three prior cases and that United States under those cases is entitled to judgment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Although the states have made admirable efforts to persuade us that that those cases should be overruled, we declined to disturb them.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Our reasons for our conclusions are given in an opinion on file with the clerk.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And as I say, we have concluded the judgment to be on the United States and it is so ordered. Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the decision or consideration of the case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.text: These cases are here by way of a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.text: The respondents who are a certified class of present and former employees brought this action against the petitioners, their employer, the Albemarle Paper Company and the other petitioner, the employee's union, seeking injunctive relief against "any policy, practice, custom or usage" at the plant which was violative of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended by the Equal Employment Opportunity Act of 1972, and after several years of discovery moved to add a class backpay demand in that lawsuit -- in this lawsuit.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1288, Alfred Dunhill of London against the Republic of Cuba will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case, which is here on certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, arises out of the 1960 expropriation of certain Cuban cigar businesses by the Republic Cuba, and their operations thereafter by government representatives called interventors.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: At the time of seizure, petitioner Alfred Dunhill Incorporated and other american of Cuban cigars owed various amounts to the Cuban companies for cigars purchased prior to the seizure.

Alfred Dunhill Of London, Inc. v. Cuba.speaker: Justice White
Alfred Dunhill Of London, Inc. v. Cuba.case_name: Alfred Dunhill Of London, Inc. v. Cuba
Alfred Dunhill Of London, Inc. v. Cuba.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 24, 1976

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals affirmed, except with respect to the affirmative judgment, which it reversed on the grounds that the sum, mistakenly paid by Dunhill, had been the subject of an act of state, and that the Republic of Cuba was therefore not open to judgment in the courts of the United States.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We granted certiorari and in an opinion filed today, we hold that no act of state was proved in the courts below with respect to the funds paid by Dunhill for cigars purchased prior to the expropriation.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is accordingly reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed a concurring opinion, and Mr. Justice Stevens, a statement agreeing with parts one and two of the filed opinion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He is joined by Justices Brennan, Stewart, and Blackmun.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-628, Allenberg Cotton Company against Pittman will be announced by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the Supreme Court of Mississippi.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: The appellant is a cotton merchant with the place of business in Memphis, Tennessee and he purchases cotton through a broker in Mississippi from people who raise cotton.

Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc. v. Pittma.speaker: Justice Douglas
Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc. v. Pittma.case_name: Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc. v. Pittman
Allenberg Cotton Company, Inc. v. Pittma.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - NOVEMBER 19, 1974

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: The appellant in the state courts in Mississippi to recover under the contract against the farmer, the planter.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: And the Mississippi court refused recovery because appellant had not received a certificate to do business in the state.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: We reversed the judgment of the Supreme Court of the State of Mississippi.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: The pattern of business is set forth in the opinion filed with the Court suffice to say that we conclude since the appellant was engaged in interstate business selling to cotton mills here and abroad and transact it and then engaging in transactions on the cotton exchange.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: He was in interstate commerce and that this regulation of Mississippi would be a direct burden on -- upon commerce.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Accordingly we reverse and remand.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well then your questions presented on page four of the jurisdictional statement, you certainly didn't raise any question like that, did you and that's all that's before the court.

context.speaker: Mason D. Morisset
context.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In any event, my question shall be regarded as to state counsel and perhaps he can explain it?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Before you leave the question of these alloted lands that Mr. Justice Rehnquist was puzzled about, when the land is alloted, will you clarify for me, is that alloted the way a conveyance of the farm land, piece of farm land is alloted by meats and bounds description or other specific description?

context.speaker: Mason D. Morisset
context.text: Now that's -- that's a difficult fact question because it differs from reservation to reservation.

context.speaker: Mason D. Morisset
context.text: But in most cases, the Bureau of Indian Affairs or in the early years, the war department carried out some kind of survey and many of these reservation lands have government, special government plats.

context.speaker: Mason D. Morisset
context.text: This Court has held that hunting and fishing rights are a Tribal right to be exercised by the individual Indians and we believe that the Colville Confederated Tribes can and will regulate this tribal right.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I gather you have to be a member of the tribe, an enrolled member?

context.speaker: Mason D. Morisset
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I notice, as the wife in discussing with Mr. Justice Blackmun, you have a footnote in the jurisdictional statement that she is an Indian but not an enrolled member of the Tribe.

context.speaker: Mason D. Morisset
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, how does that place your position as to --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Supreme Court of Washington held that the Supremacy Clause did not have that effect since the state had not been a party to the 1891 Agreement and accordingly affirm the convictions of the appellant Indians for hunting deer out of season.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold the congressional ratification of the 1891 Agreement constituted the provision reserving hunting and fishing rights by force of the Supremacy Clause, the supreme law superior and paramount to the authority of Washington and neither the participation of Washington as a party to the agreement or an expressed provision in the statute, ratification statute precluding state authority or the consent of the state was required to achieve that result.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-2060, Austin against New Hampshire will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In this case, the appellants, residents of Maine have challenged a New Hampshire Commuters Income Tax under which their income earned in New Hampshire is taxed while the earned income of New Hampshire residents no matter where earned are not taxed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: A prior decision of this Court established that in the area of taxation, the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Article IV of the constitution required that non-residents be treated on terms of substantial equality with residents.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: A prior decision of this Court established that in the area of taxation, the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Article IV of the constitution required that non-residents be treated on terms of substantial equality with residents.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The actual effect of the New Hampshire Commuters Tax however, if exact from the non-residents the wholly disproportionate share of the costs of government.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Therefore, for reasons stated in an opinion filed today with the clerk, we hold the tax statute unconstitutional under the Privileges and Immunities Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1869, Beer against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act prohibits a state or any of its political subdivisions which are subject to Section 4 of the Act from enforcing, and I quote the statutory language, any voting qualification or prerequisite to voting or standard, practice or procedure with respect to voting different from that in force or effect on November 1, 1964, unless it has obtained a declaratory judgment from the District Court for the District of Columbia that such change, again the statutory language, does not have the purpose and will not have the effect of denying or abridging the right to vote on account of race or color or has submitted the proposed change to the Attorney General, and the Attorney General has not objected to it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It is undisputed that the reapportionment plan in question, adopted in 1971, will have the effect of substantially improving the position of Negro citizens in New Orleans with respect to their effective exercise of the electoral franchise.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in some detail in the Courts written opinion, we hold that an ameliorative new legislative apportionment, such as this, can not violate Section 5 unless the new apportionment itself so discriminates on the basis of race or color as to violate the constitution, and there is no claim in this case that this reapportionment is unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the District Court is set aside and the case is remanded to that court for further proceedings consistent with the written opinion filed today with the clerk.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has also filed a dissenting opinion which Mr. Justice Brennan has joined and Mr. Justice Stevens took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: D. Patrick Lacy, Jr.
context.text: Precisely, yes sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And do you think your statute 18.163, as it existed, went that far?

context.speaker: D. Patrick Lacy, Jr.
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And it says if any person by publication much your advertisement or by the sale or circulation of any publication, wouldn't that cover Mr. Justice Brennan's hypothetical?

context.speaker: D. Patrick Lacy, Jr.
context.text: The sale circulation, I think it's the economic activity, obviously it probably would in that particular instance.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: So the New York Times is in trouble if it carries its ads on the paper of Virginia?

context.speaker: D. Patrick Lacy, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: That simply means that it's the one that's performed by someone other than a physician then?

context.speaker: D. Patrick Lacy, Jr.
context.text: Precisely, we had -- we have to follow the decisions of this Court in Roe v. Wade and Doe v. Bolton.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But they have nothing to do with advertising of medical services as I think Mr. Justice Powell pointed out.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think the offense agreed to without and by implication.

context.speaker: D. Patrick Lacy, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1309, Bigelow against Virginia will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us on appeal from the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth, Virginia.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The appellant, Mr. Bigelow is the managing editor of a weekly newspaper published in Charlottesville.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The State of course, has an interest in the welfare and health of its citizens.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It may seek to disseminate information so as to enable its citizens to make better informed decisions when they leave the borders of the state.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: But it may not, under the guise of exercising internal police powers, bar a citizen of another State from disseminating information about activity that is legal in that other State.

Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores.case_name: Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores
Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 24, 1975

context.speaker: Allyn O. Kreps
context.text: I do not think you can reconcile the reasoning or purported reasoning of the majority panel below with the panel in Mount Clemens and when we petitioned for a rehearing en banc, the panel in Mount Clemens voted for granting that rehearing en banc and we felt -- we received five votes and failed just one vote short of getting a rehearing en banc in the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Allyn O. Kreps
context.text: I think if we had had that rehearing, the outcome would have been different because I can seen intellectual basis for distinguishing the majority decision of the panel below from overruling Birnbaum.

context.speaker: Allyn O. Kreps
context.text: They simply tried to ride around it because I think they were unduly impressed by the allegations of the amended complaint here.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Kreps, I noticed that neither you nor your opponent seem to have cited Justice Stewart's opinion for the Court last year in the Amtrak case where the Court held that provision of one type of civil remedy excluded another.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I should think in view of the provision of Section 11 and 12 of the Act of 1933 that might be of some significance to your case.

context.speaker: Allyn O. Kreps
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I concur that it is in so particularly on the -- another issue that is attempted to be raised by the SEC at the last minute and that is whether there is a private remedy under Section 17 of the 1933 Act other than is set forth in Section 12 (2) of the 1933 Act.

Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores.case_name: Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores
Blue Chip Stamps v. Manor Drug Stores.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 09, 1975

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Efforts to change this longstanding rule by amendment of the statute have been uniformly unsuccessful and there is considerable evidence that the Birnbaum rule reflects the intention of Congress as expressed in the 1933 and 1934 Acts.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Since respondent Manor Drug is neither a purchaser nor a seller of securities as defined in the 1934 Act and required by the Birnbaum rule, it cannot bring a 10b-5 damage action.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is therefore reversed.

context.text: I mean, I think that context is the very vital thing.

context.speaker: Craig Eldon Pinkus
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But the difference is that he was using it because he was repeating it out of a record in a case before the Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There may have been some question about his good taste in judgment in using it instead of letting us read it, but he wasn't using that language in the sense that Mr. Justice Blackmun is talking about.

context.speaker: Craig Eldon Pinkus
context.text: Well sir, I'm arguing that context is extremely vital and that -- to simply pick out a word and say this word is always inappropriate in a student publication goes very, very far beyond what the First Amendment should be permitted to tolerate and I would like to stress that we have quite a double standard.

context.speaker: Craig Eldon Pinkus
context.text: These words are in the dictionaries, they are in the New York Times, they are in the Wall Street Journal reporting comments from presidential tapes.

context.text: And of the course the burden of showing the admissibility of the in-custody statements of persons illegally arrested rest upon the prosecution.

context.speaker: Richard C. Turner
context.text: I can't see --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Government agrees with you too that on the statute the fetus is not a child and --

context.speaker: Richard C. Turner
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: -- but nevertheless, aid can be given as Mr. Justice Brennan suggested.

context.speaker: Richard C. Turner
context.text: Yes sir, but there is no -- nothing in the statute that says that that can be done and they can't simply --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We care about the letter issue, do you?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You do not think that the existence of the federal contribution requires a uniform treatment on this subject throughout the United States?

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: The states have a wide latitude and that's been uniformly recognized by this Court in terms of setting need standard.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: How is this kind of a context however as Mr. Justice Rehnquist suggested?

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: Your Honor, no --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Is there any case which you rely on specifically other than Dandridge that you referred to which (Voice Overlap)?

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: That's correct Your Honor and --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And the welfare system does the same thing?

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: That's correct Your Honor although --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: As Mr. Justice Blackmun has pointed out there's a different approach in the General Revenue Code and the Social Security Act?

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: Your Honor, I think that in terms of the distinction there are at least a couple of points.

context.speaker: Robert Bartels
context.text: One is in -- for one thing is an administrative matter Congress might have or decided with regard to the collection of taxes that administratively it was better to wait until the child was actually born and to avoid the situation for example in which the child was conceived on December 30th and then the family will get a tax exemption from the entire year.

context.text: The judgment and opinion in No. 73-5520, Cantrell v. Forest City Publishing Company will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is a diversity of citizenship action, brought in a Federal District Court, grounded upon invasion of the petitioner's privacy.

Cantrell v. Forest City Publishing Compa.speaker: Justice Stewart

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is a diversity of citizenship action, brought in a Federal District Court, grounded upon invasion of the petitioner's privacy.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The jury returned a verdict for the plaintiffs but this judgment was reversed by the Court of Appeals under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons stated in some detail in the opinion filed today, we hold that with respect to two of the defendants, the Cleveland Plain Dealer and one of its reporters, the trial judge did not commit constitutional error in allowing the case to go to the jury under the instructions that he gave and we therefore reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The jury returned a verdict for the plaintiffs but this judgment was reversed by the Court of Appeals under the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons stated in some detail in the opinion filed today, we hold that with respect to two of the defendants, the Cleveland Plain Dealer and one of its reporters, the trial judge did not commit constitutional error in allowing the case to go to the jury under the instructions that he gave and we therefore reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: William J. Schafer, III
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But you draw no distinction between the result of a plea of guilty and any other type of conviction, do you?

context.speaker: William J. Schafer, III
context.text: No, I do not, Your Honor, and--

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, I thought Justice Stewart's inquiry of you was that you can't even indict for a 1580 until you have the first conviction.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I take it, you can under Arizona practice.

context.speaker: William J. Schafer, III
context.text: Your Honor.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: There's a lot that could happen between--

context.speaker: Frederick S. Klein
context.text: That would be my feeling.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That verdict and a judicial conviction.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And, yet, the Arizona Court of Appeals is clearly in accord with Justice Brennan's comment, isn't it?

context.speaker: Frederick S. Klein
context.text: I don't believe they are, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Frederick S. Klein
context.text: I believe that they would be in accord with my view point that a conviction must be proven, but that the element involved-- that conviction is merely a form of proof of commission.

context.speaker: John D. Kelly
context.text: All three judges reside in North Dakota.

context.speaker: John D. Kelly
context.text: Judge Bright is of course on the circuit court of appeal.

context.speaker: John D. Kelly
context.text: So they all reside in North Dakota.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Kelly, may I tend for minute to the question asked to you earlier by Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Are you complaining about the multimember districts for members of House of Representatives as well as the Senate?

context.speaker: John D. Kelly
context.text: Insofar as we're complaining if it means that we're going to have a district, a House district with 10 members, but we're willing to concede that in accordance with the traditions of North Dakota that a district that would be comprised of one senator and two house members which is what the original decision of Judge Benson or Judge Bright and Judge Van Sickle was back in 1972, we're willing to accept that because that is not a large multimember district and it is historically in accordance with our traditions and it would seem to me not confronts the people of North Dakota with the type of problems that they are involved with now in terms of large districts, involving large numbers of people so --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1406, Chapman against Meier will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case concerns the constitutionality of a reapportionment of the North Dakota legislature.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The somewhat unusual features of the reapportionment was ordered by a federal court and is not one affected by the legislature itself.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We also hold that a population variance of such magnitude as 20% is impermissible in a Court ordered plan in the absence of significant state policies or other acceptable considerations that require the plan's adoption.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The burden is on the Court to elucidate the reasons -- necessitate any departure from the goal of population equality and to articulate the relationship between the variance and the state policy furthered. We conclude that the allowance of the variance here was not appropriately justified.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The judgment of the three-judge court is therefore reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart will announce a group of three consolidated cases and two consolidated cases.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Taking the three first, they are No. 73-1380, Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians and others against the Federal Power Commission and others, No. 73-1666 Arizona Public Service Company and others, Petitioners, against the Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians, and 73-1667, the Federal Power Commission, Petitioner, against the Chemehuevi Tribe of Indians and others.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In these three cases, we review a single judgment of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to determine whether thermal electric power generating plants that draw cooling water from navigable streams are subject to the licensing jurisdiction of the Federal Power Commission under Part I of the Federal Power Act.

City of Richmond v. United States.speaker: Justice White
City of Richmond v. United States.case_name: City of Richmond v. United States
City of Richmond v. United States.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 24, 1975

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We do not agree with the District Court that the annexation has finely conceived have the effect of denying the right to vote.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We are also sufficiently unsure that it had the purpose -- that it had such a purpose that we vacate the judgment of the District Court and remand the case for further proceedings with respect to the purpose of the annexation in the light of present conditions.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: These conclusions are more fully explained in the opinion filed with the clerk today.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed an opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Now, appellant has pointed out several cases attempting to argue that the tax imposed by the statute is a license tax as a conditioned precedent for doing business in Louisiana and several -- the several cases pointed out by appellant brought up that issue that you just asked.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: These cases were cited by the Louisiana Supreme Court when it held that the requirement that the state qualify, I mean, the corporation qualify in the state in order to be able to use the courts of the state only apply to corporations doing intrastate business.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: It did not apply corporation doing exclusively interstate business.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Have I heard your answer to Justice Stewart's question which I think followed mine as to whether in your opinion Louisiana have the power to tax the doing of interstate business in an individual where sole proprietorship or a partnership on?

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Yes, I did answer that.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: They would if they gave to the individual -- to the partnership, benefits, local benefits emanating from the State of Louisiana, emanating from the sovereign power of the State of Louisiana.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: However, he would not have the right to receive the corporate benefits that Colonial does.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Now, I would like to point out that --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Could you answer my Brother Blackmun's question?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Or Mr. Justice Stewart's question.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Oh, yeah.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It's really the same question.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: They would pay the corporate franchise tax imposed by the statute in question.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: I would also like to point out that Colonial when they built their pipeline across the State of Louisiana utilized the state's courts for their appropriation of the -- of various properties and to build their pipeline.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Their appropriation powers came from the state, the state gave to the common carriers and to petroleum pipelines the right to utilize appropriation powers in the state courts to build their pipeline.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, if the -- if the individual that was postulated by I think Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun had started this pipeline in Texas and went all the way to the east coast, what would be the situation on -- would he be able to condemn lands?

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Would it be a common carrier?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: It's a common carrier.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: They would pay the corporate franchise tax imposed by the statute in question.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: I would also like to point out that Colonial when they built their pipeline across the State of Louisiana utilized the state's courts for their appropriation of the -- of various properties and to build their pipeline.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Their appropriation powers came from the state, the state gave to the common carriers and to petroleum pipelines the right to utilize appropriation powers in the state courts to build their pipeline.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, if the -- if the individual that was postulated by I think Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun had started this pipeline in Texas and went all the way to the east coast, what would be the situation on -- would he be able to condemn lands?

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: Would it be a common carrier?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: It's a common carrier.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: They would not levy this tax and the state is not attempting to levy this tax on the individual.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: It is in fact a corporation tax.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: It is imposed only on corporations for the privilege of existing in corporate form.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: What Mr. Justice Stewart said, "We're not talking about exactly what the state has done here."

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We're speaking of constitutional power and I wonder would you ever answer that question?

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: I attempted and I'll attempt to do it again and that is this.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Are there any other benefits that Colonial receives from Louisiana?

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: The benefits are the normal corporate benefits that any other corporation, domestic or foreign receives.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: But don't they have a fire protection all the rest to this kind of thing and is this answered by Mr. Justice Marshall's comment or that's taken care of by the property tax?

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: No, sir.

context.speaker: Whit M. Cook, II
context.text: The property tax in Louisiana is a local tax by the local parishes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1595, Colonial Pipeline Company against Traigle will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here from the Supreme Court of Louisiana.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The appellant, Colonial Pipeline Company is an interstate pipeline engaged exclusively in interstate business.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The appellant, Colonial Pipeline Company is an interstate pipeline engaged exclusively in interstate business.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Louisiana Supreme Court held however that as a foreign corporation qualified to carry on and actually carrying on business in Louisiana in corporate form, Colonial gained the benefits and protections from Louisiana, a value and importance to its business and therefore that Colonial can be required to pay Louisiana's franchise tax without violating the Commerce Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We agree and affirmed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun has filed a concurring opinion in which Mr. Justice Rehnquist joins.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 73-1256, Connell Construction Company versus Steamfitters Local No. 100 will be delivered by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case comes to us from the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The petitioner is a general contractor in a construction business in Dallas.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: For the reasons stated in our opinion filed today, we hold that the agreement between the union and the contractor is not immune from federal antitrust laws.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We remand the case to determine whether in fact, this agreement was an illegal restraint of trade.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We also hold that state antitrust laws are preempted by federal labor policy.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr Justice Stewart filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas also filed a brief dissenting statement.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1908, Cort against Ash will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is also here on certiorari from the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Petitioner Cort, who is Chairman of the Board of Directors of Bethlehem Steel Corporation, he and his follow directors authorized the use of corporate moneys during the 1972 Presidential campaign to pay for political advertisements in various newspapers and magazines purporting to refute statements of the Democratic candidate, George McGovern, that corporations did not carry their fair share of the tax burden.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Amendments creating that Commission expressly require that complaints of irregularities in the future campaigns must be filed with the Commission and empowers the Commission to decide whether to request the Attorney General to file a civil action for injunctive relief.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Since our duty is to decide this case according to the law existing at the time of our decision, respondent then must file with the Commission any complaints he may make of irregularities in connection with future campaigns and cannot maintain this action at this juncture for injunctive relief.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We also reverse the judgment insofar as respondent seeks damages derivatively as stockholder, although the fact that violation of a criminal statute is charged does not necessarily preclude implication of a private cause of action for damages, we can find no indication whatever in the legislative history of the 1970 Amendments that suggest a congressional intention to vest in corporate shareholders a private federal right to sue for damages for its violation if they have such a right they must seek it under state law.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: It's not totally vacated.

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: Your driver's license may be yanked.

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: If you're on probation, you will automatically be sent to jail and those collateral consequences are very severe and this Court has affirmed those collateral consequences in the case last term.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I thought you just admitted to Mr. Justice White that you could nullify that entire effect?

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: You can't nullify the collateral consequences you see because of the fact in the Massachusetts procedure, the statutes that empower the registrar say to yank your motor vehicle license.

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: They're entirely separate.

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Wait a minute, is this being found innocent in the District Court?

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: Yes, the District Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think Mr. Justice White asked you suppose you're found innocent in the Superior Court.

context.speaker: Robert W. Hagopian
context.text: Well, then yes, then you are declared innocent and then the registrar has to give you your license back but you see, it's that intervening time between the District Court and the Superior Court that is the nub of the matter.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Do you say the judgment basis in fact --

context.speaker: Jerome H. Torshen
context.text: I think the associational rights here, as this Court pointed out in Pontikes versus Kusper, are the rights of the voters to associate with other members of the party in selecting their representatives.

context.speaker: Jerome H. Torshen
context.text: And secondly, to associate with other members in an election process that here is concededly free, equal, open and non-discriminatory to select those representatives.

context.speaker: Jerome H. Torshen
context.text: And third, if we must, the right of the state parties themselves to associate through their duly elected representatives with the representatives of other state parties in the convention, so that they can choose the nominees for one of our major parties.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What about the question that Mr. Justice White put to Mr. Whalen, Mr. Torshen?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What if the Democratic National Party decides, we don't want popular elected delegates to our convention.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We want one just chosen by state conventions, is it free to go ahead on that basis even though Illinois law says that delegates to National Convention shall be chosen in an election?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion in 73-1106, Cousins against Wigoda will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on certiorari from the Appellate Court of the State of Illinois.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It involves a contest between two slates of delegates who sought to be seated as the delegation from Chicago to the 1972 Democratic National Convention.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Illinois Appellate Court affirmed the injunction holding that the right to seat as a delegate representing Illinois at the National nominating convention is governed exclusively by the Illinois Election Code and that the interest of the state in protecting the effective right to participate in primaries is superior to whatever other interests the party itself might wish to protect.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse in the selection of candidates for national office a national party convention serves the pervasive national interest which is paramount to any interest of a state in protecting the integrity of a electoral process and the Illinois courts therefore erred in issuing an injunction that abridged the associational rights of petitioners and their party protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thus, this is a case where the convention itself was the proper forum for determining intraparty disputes as to which delegate should be seated.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed an opinion concurring in the result in which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Stewart have joined.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.text: We reverse in the selection of candidates for national office a national party convention serves the pervasive national interest which is paramount to any interest of a state in protecting the integrity of a electoral process and the Illinois courts therefore erred in issuing an injunction that abridged the associational rights of petitioners and their party protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thus, this is a case where the convention itself was the proper forum for determining intraparty disputes as to which delegate should be seated.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed an opinion concurring in the result in which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Stewart have joined.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thus, this is a case where the convention itself was the proper forum for determining intraparty disputes as to which delegate should be seated.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: That was on the motion for rehearing.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: So the statute is essential to blind liability on this lawsuit and that's what the opinion on motion for rehearing makes clear beginning on page 824?

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I would suppose your answer to Justice Rehnquist to be that Mills against Alabama is your case that would indicate there might be jurisdiction here rather than the Citizens for Better Austin against Keefe which is an injunction case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mills against Alabama was not.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: Mills versus Alabama, the only reason I didn't -- we rely on our brief on Mills versus Alabama also in North Dakota Pharmacy, Snyder, and Tornillo.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: As in Tornillo, where there were defenses on a remand or likewise there will be some defenses that we would have and that's why I didn't use in argument the Mills versus Alabama case.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: But the defenses are -- would not, the defenses would not involve the First Amendment.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: We would try to deal as, it's like libel, we would try to submit to show that the plaintiff had not had his invasion -- his privacy invaded and it was not offensive but we think that that question that that should not be submitted to the trial court, and that's we you should take possibly appeal here.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, my question here it was not a just to the jurisdictional issue contrary to Justice Stewart suggest and I think you responded along the lines I have anticipated but you style this as a prior restraint and I have thought that the distinction in our cases was that a prior restraint was something that you're prohibited from doing in advance of trying to do with.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Here, there was no prohibition, there was no injunction that you would be in contempt of, if you want to have them publish this and you're simply being subjected to damages is afterwards like in a libel case.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: It's a misdemeanor action Your Honor under the Georgia law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Nobody is prosecuting it.

context.speaker: Kirk M. McAlpin
context.text: Well, on the other hand, there was a prosecution and he view in the Wisconsin case in South California maybe our case they rely upon --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But nobody is prosecuting you and under Georgia law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Even if they were that wouldn't be a prior restraint, Mr. Justice Rehnquist is so correct.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Prior restraint has a rather technical meaning and that's not involved here.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Post -- after the fact, you got a criminal or civil liability has nothing to do with the prior restraint.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion in 73-938, Cox Broadcasting Corporation against Cohn will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia and that Court sustained a statute of the state which forbad the press under any circumstances to publish the name of a rape victim.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: There is an initial question about jurisdiction and we answer it and sustain our jurisdiction for the reasons which we given an opinion which is on file with the clerk.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the Supreme Court of Georgia and that Court sustained a statute of the state which forbad the press under any circumstances to publish the name of a rape victim.

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: On the ceded land?

context.speaker: Bertram E. Hirsch
context.text: That on the ceded lands, it's definitely clear, in terms of our position here today, it's definitely clear, that the tribe has complete civil jurisdiction over non-Indians.

context.speaker: Bertram E. Hirsch
context.text: When an Indian is a defendant in a civil action and perhaps even when a non-Indian is a defendant in a civil action, what --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Your answer to Mr. Justice Blackmun's question upon though was that yes, this case does involve all those people, all those non-Indians for the said reservation.

context.speaker: Bertram E. Hirsch
context.text: But not necessarily to the all inclusive extent to what Mr. Justice Blackmun was perhaps getting to, and that is that where the action is between two non-Indians then the tribe's jurisdiction --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What's the authority of the state over a non-Indian, living on a ceded land, what about that state's criminal law?

DeCoteau v. District County Court for th.speaker: Justice Rehnquist

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That will be be my opinion, yes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But if he is shot by an Indian.

context.speaker: William F. Day, Jr.
context.text: Be Federal, it could be one of the ten major crimes which would be exclusively in the Federal Court then.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: No, does your answer to Mr. Justice Blackmun's question there depend in any respect on whether or not this is an Indian reservation or whether it was all ceded?

context.speaker: William F. Day, Jr.
context.text: On white on white, it's not going to make any difference, but sir where you have problems or where you could have, since 1891 the State of South Dakota has assumed jurisdiction over all of this area, except on the allotments over Indians and Whites.

context.speaker: William F. Day, Jr.
context.text: Now, you have a situation, if Feather holds up, where if you have an Indian and a white in a fight for example, so the state court is going to have to go out and arrest the white man, the Tribal Court's going to have to go out and arrest the Indian.

context.speaker: William F. Day, Jr.
context.text: No.

context.text: How do you know?

context.text: I don't believe, we did.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: They are doing all of this record then publicly or do they in the Eighth Circuit, I'm not familiar, Mr. Justice Blackmun knows the practice.

context.speaker: William F. Day, Jr.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In No. 73-1148 -- I should have said in the previous three cases that Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of those cases.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In No. 73-1148, Cheryl Spider DeCoteau, Natural Mother and Next Friend of Robert Lee Feather and Herbert John Spider versus the The District County Court for the Tenth Judicial District of South Dakota.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And in 73-1500, Don R. Erickson, Warden, Petitioner, against John Lee Feather and others, Respondent.

DeCoteau v. District County Court for th.speaker: Justice Stewart

DeCoteau v. District County Court for th.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 03, 1975

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The parties agree that the state courts did not have jurisdiction if these lands are "Indian country," as statutorily defined, and that this question depends upon whether the lands retained reservation status after 1891 Act of Congress.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We hold, for the reasons discussed at some length in the Court's written opinion filed this morning with the clerk that the 1891 Act terminated the Lake Traverse Reservation, and that consequently the state courts have jurisdiction over conduct on non-Indian lands within the 1867 reservation borders.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment in No. 73-1148 is affirmed and the judgment in 73-1150 is reversed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion to which Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall have subscribed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Herbert Kassner

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: Yes Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But his--but what Judge Oakes says is we agree with the District Court as to the probability of success on the merits.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 74-337, Doran against Salem Inn, Incorporated will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The respondents in this case which comes to us from the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit are three corporations which operate bars in North Hempstead, New York.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: For a number of years they each entertained their customers by presenting topless dancing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Because the lower courts did nothing more than grant preliminary relief we did not -- we need not decide whether respondents are entitled to prevail on the merits of their First Amendment contentions, we merely decided in the light of existing case law and of the broad reach of North Hempstead's ordinance which extends far beyond the control of topless dancing in establishments serving alcoholic beverage and of the possibility that respondents would suffer bankruptcy were the ordinance enforced while their rights were being litigated.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The District Court did not abuse its discretion in issuing a preliminary injunction in their behalf.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore affirm in part and reverse in part the judgment of the Second Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed an opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The District Court did not abuse its discretion in issuing a preliminary injunction in their behalf.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore affirm in part and reverse in part the judgment of the Second Circuit.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: In summary of point one I would like to emphasize at here we are concerned not with mental illness or mental abnormalities or sexual perversions or sociopathic tendencies, but we are concerned with the ability of the petitioner to understand the charge against him, the facts against him, to understand the proceedings against him, to consult with his counsel, to communicate and to assist and aid in his defense.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: I think if you look through the facts, brought forth by the petitioner's counsel which at first blush might suggest a bona fide doubt is to produce a counsel of proceed.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: A close analysis of those facts indicate --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr MacFarlane I suppose that the easiest thing to do would have been to give him the examination promptly at the course of the trial as Mr. Justice White suggests than we wouldn't have the case here.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: Your Honor, he was given a hearing at the motion for new trial, on his motion for a new trial which went only to absence from the trial, it did not going to his mental competency at all.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: That perhaps would have been a better way to proceed would be to have, to have mentally -- give him a mental examination or psychiatric examination.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: So there would have been an opportunity, but it would have been prior to that statement.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Of course, the traditional way, even after the judge had spoken would be to make an offer of prove to say that, if the court will permit, I will call two psychiatrists whose testimony will be substantially as follows, that's the traditional way of deserving the point is it not?

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: Yes, it certainly is Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But then at the close of the trial, when the motion was made for a new trial, did I understand you and responding to Mr. Justice White, to say that there was no proffer of any testimony on the subject of his competency?

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Neil MacFarlane
context.text: It simply went to his absence from trial not as to his mental ability to voluntary wave his right to be present.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree and reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We agree that the decision not to file suit is not immune from judicial review.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold, however, that that review was limited to the determination whether a statement of reasons informing the Court and the complaining union member of the grounds of the Secretary's decision and the essential facts upon which it is based shows within the four corners of the statement itself that the Secretary's decision was rationally based or shows rather that the decision was arbitrary and capricious.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Yes, but the proposition expressed that went beyond supervision of the Federal Judicial system.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The Court said that the American tradition of trial by jury in criminal or civil cases necessarily contemplates an impartial jury drawn from a cross-section of the community.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, what -- the state could try these civil cases without any jury at all as far as any decision this Court is concerned?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Yes the -- well, at least I should put it even if there is no Seventh Amendment right to jury trial in a state court, once the State does provide a jury trial Justice White, the State does provide a grand jury though it's not required, then its selection and procedures become subject to equal protection and due process scrutiny as does any other state action.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: On the merits, Hoyt against Florida upheld the statute virtually identical to the scheme at issue here and indeed this court has not yet explicitly reconsidered its 1880 dictum in Strauder against West Virginia, 100 U.S. at 310, that a state may constitutionally confine jury duty to males after Strauder, but before Hoyt in 1947 and Fay v. New York, 332 U.S.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The blue ribbon jury was contested but also in New York's automatic exemption of women, the Court upheld that women don't need exemption and in the process indicated that women might be beyond the pale of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The three concurring justices were unable to say based on the Hoyt record that Florida failed to make an effort to have women perform jury duty and the majority opinion suggests that appellant Hoyt had not ruled out other circumstances for chance as one of the reasons for the porosity of women jurors.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But in the instant case, it is not disputed that the Louisiana selection system and only that system not other circumstances and not chance, produces jury list that rarely include any woman's name.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Based on the stipulated facts, the court below found that Louisiana's benign dispensation, not chance yields jury panels that never include more than 5% women and frequently less.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Significantly Mr. Justice Douglas, who concurred in Hoyt later acknowledged that inevitably, a volunteer's only system results in almost as total an exclusion as would obtain in women were not permitted to serve at all for --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In there any variation among the counties or parishes is I guess you call them in Louisiana?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I had not made a survey but I think that the stipulation was generous that not more than 10% are I think, I suppose less.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Hoyt court, never adverted to all the unemployed women, who do not have childcare responsibilities, that was another factor and the third factor was the concentration in Hoyt on the woman as potential juror.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This was a benign dispensation of favor to her, she could serve if she wanted to, but she had no responsibility to serve.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In my respect it was somewhat like Shevin against Kahn, wasn't it?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Now that action -- in that action, the defendant's crime was committed after an altercation in which she claimed her husband had insulted and humiliated her to the breaking point, convicted of second degree murder by an all-male jury.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-130, Ellis against Dyson and 73-1543, Johnson against The Railway Express Agency will each be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: For the first case, Ellis against Dyson comes to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The petitioners here were convicted and fined by the Municipal Court of the City of Dallas on their pleas of nolo contendere for violating the Dallas loitering ordinance.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Fifth Circuit's opinion on which the District Court had relied was subsequently reversed in our case entitled Steffel against Thompson.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We there held that federal declaratory relief was not precluded when a state prosecution based upon an assertedly unconstitutional state statute had been threatened but was not pending.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: As a consequence, we reversed the Court of Appeals' judgment and remand the case to the District Court for reconsideration on the light of Steffel as to whether there is a genuine threat of prosecution here and as to the relationship between the past prosecution of the petitioners and the alleged threat of future prosecutions.

context.speaker: Kenneth Hecht
context.text: If you can go the Union, the Union can bring it to the employer.

context.speaker: Kenneth Hecht
context.text: If you can affect the remedy, good.

context.speaker: Kenneth Hecht
context.text: The employees abandoned the Union only when the futility of their staying with the Union became clear, and when the Union had told them that they were free to undertake the individual action that they intended to take.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: So that what you're saying, I take it is that when the members of the Union, any members of the Union are not satisfied with the Union's result for them and for their claims, then they may engage in typical collective bargaining type of protest that is Union picketing, the same kind of technique that the Union uses to enforce?

context.speaker: Kenneth Hecht
context.text: No.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1942, Erznoznik against Jacksonville -- the City of Jacksonville, and 74-634, United States against Nobles will each be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: A Jacksonville, Florida ordinance, directed at move in -- at drive-in movie theaters prohibits the exhibition of films which contain nudity.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The ordinance was sustained by the Florida courts and came to us on appeal.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The intrusion on the privacy of passersby is limited.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The legitimate state interest in protecting children from obscenity is not furthered and if designed as a traffic measure, many things such as scenes of horror and violence are more likely to distract than many of the fleeting shots of nudity that abide by this ordinance.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In sum, although a city or a state has a legitimate interest that would support a non-discriminatory ordinance regulating drive-in theaters this ordinance unduly infringes upon First Amendment rights with little prospect of furthering any of the legitimate state interest.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The Chief Justice filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice White also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Does that policy suggest something about this case?

context.speaker: Jerome B. Falk, Jr.
context.text: I think not, because of the difference between the prosecutor's interest in having a jury trial, and the prosecutor's lack of interest in seeing that the defendant has a particular type of defense.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Does it not go to what Mr. Justice Blackmun was intimating that the state has such a strong interest in a proper trial that it sets up these additional safeguards over and above the constitution?

context.speaker: Jerome B. Falk, Jr.
context.text: A whole series of questions I think all touch on the very problem of the inadequate defendant.

context.speaker: Jerome B. Falk, Jr.
context.text: He's made an intelligent waiver in the sense that he understood what he did, but he's not intelligent about being a lawyer.

context.speaker: Jerome B. Falk, Jr.
context.text: We have not gone that far, and I think that's an open question.

context.speaker: Jerome B. Falk, Jr.
context.text: I think that that standby counsel alternative plus the power of the trial judge to run his courtroom provides a very adequate answer to the problem that Mr. Justice Blackmun raised early on, which is the problem of the inadequate defendant and the need of the courts to see that everybody gets a fair trial.

context.speaker: Jerome B. Falk, Jr.
context.text: That bridges the gap.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I gather Mr. Falk, your answer to Mr. Justice Stewart means counsel -- court says Alright, go ahead defend yourself.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: He said Well, I'd like to have counsel sit behind me to help me if I need him.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: You want to run your own show, you run it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinions -- judgments and opinions of the Court in two cases, 73-5772, Faretta against California, and 73-6587, Herring against New York will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The first of these cases, Faretta against the State of California is here by way of a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of California for the Second Appellate District.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments of our Constitution guarantee that a person brought to trial in any state or federal court must be afforded the right to the assistance of counsel before he can be validly convicted and punished by imprisonment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The record affirmatively shows that Faretta was literate, competent, and understanding and that he was voluntarily exercising his informed free will.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We hold that in forcing Faretta under these circumstances to accept against his will a state appointed public defender, the California courts deprived him of his constitutional right to conduct his own defense.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment before us is vacated and the case is remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with the written opinion of the Court filed with the clerk this morning.

context.speaker: Harry R. Sachse
context.text: He may not have wanted to be in Vietnam or he may not have been able to go anywhere but God knows where on that vacation.

context.speaker: Harry R. Sachse
context.text: Now, it could have been wonderful.

context.speaker: Harry R. Sachse
context.text: It might have been two weeks in Paris, you know, but we just --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well then, it might have been a terminal leave pay as Mr. Justice Stewart suggested that the last -- and that's common with military personnel, is it not, that they are discharged as of March 30th that they leave active duty on --

context.speaker: Harry R. Sachse
context.text: There are a lot of vagaries in the military about how these things worked, we're trying to keep out that you know you can be discharged and have to go across the country and think that's wonderful or you can be discharged and be in a terrible situation.

context.speaker: Harry R. Sachse
context.text: It can be from delight to horror and --

context.text: They dealt with an exhausted issue and exhausted issues and dealt with the merits of both issues.

context.speaker: Robert E. Shepherd, Jr.
context.text: But I dont think that their refusal to do so amounts to such an abuse of their discretion as to constitute reversible error in this Court.

context.speaker: Robert E. Shepherd, Jr.
context.text: And I think that its a matter that should be left with the courts and the exercise of their discretion.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Shepherd, you sought up to bring up a couple of times the larger question or the larger position, the larger claim that a search and seizure claim is simply unavailable on federal habeas corpus that is the position taken by Mr. Justice Powell in his concurring opinion in Schneckloth against Bustamonte.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You havent develop that I might -- the question is that issue really here, did you have you ever brought it up until now in this case?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I mean --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Would all these be valid do you think?
I think it all would have to go back further to the question of whether it would be Congress would have a rational basis for determining that under the commerce power this is a necessity.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Some 30 odd years ago, it seems to me the federal government reduced the salaries of all government employees some 10% or something of that kind.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Suppose in such a period they said this is across the board, all the federal employees, all public employees, everywhere else to pursue Mr. Justice Blackmun's question.
You mean you said the federal government reduced it by 10% for --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Its own employees and all other public employees.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-822, Fry against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In Economic Stabilization Act of 1970 authorized the President to stabilize wages and salaries at certain levels, and created the Pay Board to oversee these controls.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: State employees do not derive immunity from federal regulation under the Commerce Clause merely because of their sovereign status.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Here, where the Act did not appreciably intrude on state sovereignty, but was an emergency measure, the effectiveness of federal action would have been drastically impaired if wage increases to state and legal -- and local employees were left outside the reach of the Act.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The judgment below is therefore affirmed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a separate statement.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
