context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would it be possible to have a man or a public announcement of all the factors that would relate to every type of confinement in every type of case?

context.speaker: John M. Creane
context.text: No I don't think that would be practical Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: John M. Creane
context.text: What we're --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Does not this manual section that Mr. Justice Stewart referred to communicate to an applicant that is supposed to do or she is supposed to do, whatever he or she would do to get a job if there were a no unemployment insurance.

context.speaker: John M. Creane
context.text: Well that may be what's intended but it still comes down with subjective --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Doesn't it come through?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the court in 73-848, Fusari against Steinberg will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on appeal from a three-judge District Court in Connecticut.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Appellees claiming continuing eligibility for unemployment compensation benefits challenge the validity of Connecticut procedures for determining that eligibility.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We concluded from our examination of Connecticut as revised that the changes were significant and could affect the merits of this case.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We therefore vacate the decision of the District Court and remand the case for reconsideration in light of the intervening changes in Connecticut law.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We will --

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: I want to turn if I may to the alternative basis upon which the bar can escape, if escape is the proper word, from the strictures of the Sherman Act for those truly legitimate activities which the bar has and which do need to be carried forward.

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: Now, if the bar can establish under Parker, that there has been state action and that the state has intended to replace competition.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: May I just, if I may before you get into that, I want to be sure I understand your previous point.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You say that there may be a so-called learned profession exemption, but we need not decide that here because if the exemption exists, it has to do with the pinch not worth the squeeze to use Justice Jackson's metaphor and that here the pinch was on the public?

context.speaker: Alan B. Morrison
context.text: That's certainly true, Your Honor and to the extent to which the special status of the bar becomes relevant of course it is in the rule of recent cases where like every other characteristics of a business or an industry we certainly must look to the obligations of that industry in its peculiarities.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That people in their learned profession let's say you had three or four PhD's and a couple of doctors or divinities, a divinity and maybe a dentist and an MD, all members of learned professions, but that they could conspire to violate the antitrust laws if the effect of that were on the general public, is that it?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I have the opinion for the Court and the judgment to announce in No. 74-70, Goldfarb against the Virginia State Bar.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And for reasons stated in an opinion filed with the clerk today, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-858, Gonzalez against Automatic Employees will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case has been brought here by a direct appeal under the Title 28 of the United States Code Section 1253 from an order of a three-judge court dismissing the appellant's complaint for a lack of standing.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We deferred consideration of our jurisdiction of this appeal until the hearing of the argument on the merits.

Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit U.speaker: Justice Burger
Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit U.case_name: Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit Union
Gonzalez v. Automatic Employees Credit U.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1974

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons discussed in considerable detail in the opinion filed today with the clerk, we have concluded that the District Court's order is not directly appealable to this Court because of the nature of the issues involved in this case relating as they do to the interrelationship of the three-judge court statutes and the correlative statutes conferring direct jurisdiction upon this Court of Appeals and three-judge courts, this opinion is not one that lend itself to very intelligible oral announcement.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Suffice it to say that we hold that when a three-judge court denies a plaintiff injunctive relief on grounds which if valid would have justified the solution of the Court as to that plaintiff or a refusal to request the convention of a three-judge court in the first place then review of the denial is available only in the Court of Appeals and not here.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, we vacate the judgment before us and remand the case to the District Court so that a fresh order may be entered and a timely appeal prosecuted to the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Justice Stewart.

context.text: I'm not sure Mr. Shapiro when I track that with what you said just previously about Congress is not giving the Securities Exchange Commission exclusive power but only a shared power at least I got that impression from -- I got the wrong impression.

context.speaker: Howard E. Shapiro
context.text: No, it is a shared power as we view it.

context.speaker: Howard E. Shapiro
context.text: And the answer relies in the fact as occurs elsewhere in the law that there maybe overlapping jurisdictions where the regulatory agency had some powers to compel conduct not authorized -- not otherwise authorized by the antitrust laws.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think what you say to Mr. Justice White just now that if they exercise the power then how's the antitrust jurisdiction (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Howard E. Shapiro
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: -- they misunderstand you then?

Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc..speaker: Justice Blackmun
Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc..case_name: Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc.
Gordon v. New York Stock Exchange, Inc..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 26, 1975

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In it, we endeavor to outline in detail the pervasive supervision both by way of power and by way of active regulation of the SEC over rates particularly in the last 15 years.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We conclude that the interposition of the antitrust laws on the theory that they bar fixed commission rates as per se violations of the Sherman Act would unduly interfere with the intended operation of the Securities Exchange Act.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case in other words, we hold is the different case referred to in a case decided here a decade ago called Silver against the New York Stock Exchange.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to say that Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a concurring opinion although joining the opinion of the Court.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And that Mr. Justice Stewart also has filed a concurring opinion in which Mr. Justice Brennan has joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, I have one further question, if I may, assuming there is a three-day holding here, there was no cross-petition first, there was no cross-appeal.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the court in 73-898, Goss against Lopez will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It involves the validity under the Due Process Clause having an Ohio statute which permits the principle of an Ohio school to suspend a pupil for misconduct for up to 10 days without provision of any kind for a hearing either before or after the suspension has taken place.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Until the day elected school boards, teachers and school authorities having free to exercise their informed discretion in their best interest of immature pupils in elementary and secondary schools.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: They will henceforth act at the peril of judicial challenge by any disgruntled or disappointed student.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In my view, the Court's decision is unwarranted as a matter of constitutional law and it may well deal a serious blow to public education in our country.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Davis, just -- just before lunch you were asked I believe by Justice White whether the Mississippi sales tax or the federal gas tax had provisions for passing on or separate statement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Let me ask you the same question about that Mississippi gasoline tax.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Is there any provision in the statute which imposes that tax that either requires it being passed on or prohibited being passed on or requires it to be separately stated?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1734, Gurley against Rhoden will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here from the Supreme Court of Mississippi.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Mississippi 5% sales tax is applied to the pump price of gasoline.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: That pump price is increased 13 cents represent federal and state excise taxes passed on by the retailer to the motorist.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Mississippi Supreme Court held that this does not render the sales tax an unconstitutional tax upon a tax.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We agree and affirm.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Because of the importance of the question, we granted certiorari.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: For reasons stated in an opinion filed with the clerk, without reaching the question whether Congress or the President might expressly adopt such a rule, we hold that the regulation deprives a large and already disadvantaged class of persons of an interest in liberty and violates the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment, because it was not expressly mandated by either Congress or the President and was not adopted by an agency of the federal government having any responsibility for the national interest which are asserted in justification for the rule.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moo.speaker: Justice Powell
Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moo.case_name: Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moore
Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moo.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 11, 1974

context.speaker: Edward J. Landry
context.text: Well, of course, constables have jurisdiction outside of their precinct.

context.speaker: Edward J. Landry
context.text: They can serve papers outside of their precinct but the fact of the matter is by law, they are required to reside within their precinct as are the justices of the peace.

context.speaker: Edward J. Landry
context.text: But we submit that the reason for the compelling state interest which would sustain this kind of a statute and sustain the differing kind of treatment between officers of the same class is Texas' requirement of residency within the precinct and that is the thing that distinguishes, of course, the different treatment between justices of the peace and constables on the one hand and county commissioners on the other following a redistricting of the precincts.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: But Justice Blackmun asked you before lunch whether one or two of the terms or one of these may expire December 31, are they eligible for re-election?

context.speaker: Edward J. Landry
context.text: They were eligible for the general election this year, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Edward J. Landry
context.text: In fact, one of the appellees in this case Judge Zaboroski ran this year after having been ousted as a result of the redistricting.

Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moo.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moo.case_name: Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moore
Harris County Commissioners Court v. Moo.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 11, 1974

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Well, if that were the case, you would not have been seeking a redistricting, a redoing of the redistricting plan, would you?

context.speaker: C. Anthony Friloux, Jr.
context.text: That's right because those particular people would have not complained if they had not been harmed but those who came under the alternate provisions would have been harmed and they would have been here seeking this relief.

context.speaker: C. Anthony Friloux, Jr.
context.text: There's no way you can take this statute and look at it and justify the fact that people within the same class are treated differently and officeholders within the same class are treated differently.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice White asked you a moment ago what cases from this Court you rely on to raise the federal question as to the districting requirements, what federal -- what case of this Court do you rely on?

context.speaker: C. Anthony Friloux, Jr.
context.text: You mean so far as asking them to redistrict, Your Honor?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes.

context.text: Mr. Gilleland, let me ask you one question before you sit down.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: About what is going on in Harris County now in connection with this?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: As I understand it the three-judge district court judgment was entered January 30th and on February 4, 1974, Justice Powell granted to stay and the full Court -- our full Court declined to set it aside on February 19.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, has anything happened to carry out the Commissioners Court's orders?

context.speaker: John G. Gilleland
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Edward J. Landry

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I have also for announcement the judgment and opinion of the Court in 74-456, Hill, the Attorney General of Texas against the Printing Industries of the Gulf Coast.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And here for reasons stated in an opinion filed this morning, the judgment of the District Court is vacated and the case is remanded to that Court for reconsideration in light of the new legislation and for dismissal, if the case is or becomes moot.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or the decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1723, Hill against Stone will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case comes to us from the District Court for the Northern District of Texas.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Under Texas law, only those residents of an election district who have rendered their properties for taxation are permitted to vote in local board elects -- on the elections.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And again in the City of Phoenix, we held that a general obligation of revenue bond elections are elections of general interest subject to the principles of the Kramer case.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, since the restrictions in this case serve no compelling state interest consisted election was one of general interest, the franchise restriction cannot stand.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We therefore affirm the opinion of the -- the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And again in the City of Phoenix, we held that a general obligation of revenue bond elections are elections of general interest subject to the principles of the Kramer case.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, since the restrictions in this case serve no compelling state interest consisted election was one of general interest, the franchise restriction cannot stand.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do you read the community standards language of the various opinions of this Court dealing with obscenity as mandating a jury trial in a civil proceeding where the state doesn't choose to provide one?

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Deitch
context.text: Not -- no sir.

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Deitch
context.text: But I'm saying that at least that the members of the community should the opportunity to pass upon the motion pictures not merely a judge --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But they have through the state -- they have indirectly as Mr. Justice Rehnquist suggest, by the state legislature having vested the power to decide that factual issue in a single judge instead of a jury of six or 12 people?

context.speaker: Gilbert H. Deitch
context.text: In a single judge for the motion pictures presented to him.But then you get to the question of the over breadth of the statutory scheme and his order, closing in future, in future of the showing of any motion picture --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, I know some have argued that the First Amendment requires a jury trial.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: For reasons set out at length in our opinion, we conclude that the notions of committee comity and federalism which underlie Younger are applicable when a federal court is asked to interfere with a state civil proceeding to which the state is a party and which is in aid of its criminal law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We also conclude that these same considerations require that a state litigant exhaust his state appellate remedies before being relieved of Youngers restrictions on interference with state proceedings which have already been initiated.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore vacate the judgment of the District Court and remand for further proceedings.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: James E. McLaughlin
context.text: And what I'm also saying is of course that in view of this substantive statute and in view of the fact that it requires every ingredient of a conspiracy, then we feel that Congress and the Court should not count this dual punishment.

context.speaker: James E. McLaughlin
context.text: We don't think that these petitioners should be punished twice for the same crime, and we feel that here they have been punished twice for the same crime.

context.speaker: James E. McLaughlin
context.text: Now, I would like --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In your submission in response to Mr. Justice Stewart, do I understand you correctly to say that if both offenses are submitted to the jury, the jury can take its choice but they must -- they're mutually exclusive.

context.speaker: James E. McLaughlin
context.text: They're mutually exclusive.

context.speaker: James E. McLaughlin
context.text: As I said that certainly as a minimum, I would feel that the District Court would have to tell the jury that they may not find the defendant guilty of both (Voice Overlap) substantive offense.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: Separate punishment in our view is precluded by Wharton's Rule on the theory that Congress took into account in establishing the punishment for the substantive offense all the dangers inherent in the commission of the substantive offense, including the dangers involved and any necessarily included conspiracy.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: But when the conspiracy exceeds in number, the minimum number necessary to the commission of the substantive crime, its dangers are likely to be increased also.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: And there is no reason in these circumstances to presume that Congress intended to limit the punishment where the conspiracy is greater than -- or creates dangers greater than those inherent in the substantive crime itself.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let me suggest a hypothetical to you to pursue Mr. Justice Stewart's proposition that you might have four innocent and one guilty, would this situation do it if you had a mountain resort up the borders of Nevada and four people were hired and told that it was in Nevada and that it was perfectly legal to be running the gambling operation, being professional gamblers from Las Vegas or some place.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But the one man who was running the show knows that it is in whatever is an adjacent state which makes it illegal.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What would be the situation then?

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: There are significant differences in the characteristics and consequences between traditional Wharton's Rule type offenses and a large scale gambling activities sought to be reached by this federal law.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In view of these differences as well as the purpose and legislative history of the law, we concluded that Congress intended to allow separate convictions and penalties for the conspiracy as well as for the substantive offense for violations of the gambling law.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Charles H. White, Jr.
context.text: 1(15) (a) gives the Commission power in an emergency to suspend any rule, any and all rules in effect with respect to car service.

context.speaker: Charles H. White, Jr.
context.text: Car service, in turn, is defined by 1(10) as to embrace the use to which cars are put.

context.speaker: Charles H. White, Jr.
context.text: Reading 1(10) and reading 1(15) together, the Commission must have under 1(15) and we submit it does have the ability to suspend car service rules embedded in tariffs.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Do you say that the other side of Mr. Justice White's question is that if the car moves within the designated time, the rate isn't change at all?

context.speaker: Charles H. White, Jr.
context.text: Precisely that, Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Charles H. White, Jr.
context.text: The --

context.speaker: Seymour L. Coblens
context.text: I beg your pardon.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It doesn't triple it if the car moves.

context.speaker: Seymour L. Coblens
context.text: That is true.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And this Court has upheld the demurrage charges against challenge and I guess what I want and I think that Mr. Justice White wants is what's the difference?

context.speaker: Seymour L. Coblens
context.text: The difference is in the structure of the Interstate Commerce Act, the Interstate Commerce Act only gives authority to the Interstate Commerce Commission for emergency action in the case of rules under 1(15).

context.speaker: Seymour L. Coblens
context.text: Justice Brandeis in the Pecan case which I have cited has stated that 1(15) must be very strictly construed and that it is only traditional and at that time it was traditional only to enforce rules by various -- either by prohibitions or criminal prohibition or by in some cases demurrage charges.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Section 13 of the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Act requires the filing of a claim under the Act within one year of injury.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The only question presented by this case is whether another Section of the same Act bars consideration of a claim which has been timely filed under Section 13 but which has not been the subject of an order or award by the officials charged with administration of the Act within one year after the cessation of voluntary compensation payments.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We agree.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: While Section 22 on its face is ambiguous, the legislative history indicates that Congress intended the one year time limit contained in 22 to apply only to the power to modify previously entered orders and not to the initial entry of orders on claims timely filed under Section 13.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.text: In an opinion filed today, we hold that listed and readily marketable securities owned by the corporation and purchased out of its earnings and profits are to be taken into account not at their cost of the corporation but at their net liquidation value for purposes of the impact of the accumulated earnings tax.

context.text: On the other hand, we get absolutely no assistance from any State or governmental agency in raising the funds necessary to carry on this business.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-5845, Jackson against Metropolitan Edison will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case arises out of respondent Metropolitan Edison's termination of electrical service to the residence of Catherine Jackson, the petitioner, for alleged non-payment of bills for prior utility service.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Metropolitan is a privately owned company licensed and regulated by the Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Respondent's exercise of the choice allowed by state law in this case where the initiative comes from it and not from the state does not make its action that of the state for purposes of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Pursuing Mr. Justice White's question to you, is it possible that in the removal hearing might turn into a miniature trial of the criminal charges to determine in the murder case or the break in -- a house break in, in order to determine the issues?

context.speaker: Frank R. Parker
context.text: Well, an evidentiary hearing as required by Rachel and the Court indicated that the plaintiffs or the petitioners did have an opportunity to prove that they were asked to leave the restaurant for racial reasons.

context.speaker: Frank R. Parker
context.text: Now, the state probably would not have to prove that they were guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, but certainly I think that in the Fifth Circuit decisions sustain this that the state would have to establish the elements of the crime.

context.speaker: Frank R. Parker
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Frank R. Parker
context.text: But they would have to establish the elements of defense that the petitioners were not arrested for unprotected -- for protected activity but they were arrested for unprotected activity and our contention is that the state hasn't met burden in this case.

context.speaker: Frank R. Parker

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: If those showings could be made, he also would be entitled to an injunction, Younger would not preclude it, would it?

context.speaker: Frank R. Parker
context.text: That's correct, Mr. Justice.

context.text: The judgment and opinion in No. 73-1531, Johnson against Mississippi and in 73-1977, Alyeska Pipeline Service against The Wilderness Society will each be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In the Johnson case, petitioners were charged in Mississippi courts with the illegal boycott of local businesses.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They sought to remove the cases under 28 U.S.C. 1443 (1) which permits removal when defendants and local criminal cases are denied or cannot enforce their rights under any federal law providing for equal civil rights.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The case is controlled by our prior decision in Greenwood against Peacock.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Here as there, there is no federal statute conferring any rights of the necessary kind that are being denied by these prosecutions in the Mississippi courts.

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 74-80, Kugler against Helfant and consolidated case 74-277, Helfant against Kugler will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: These two companion cases are here by reason of the grant of writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Edwin H. Helfant brought this action in a Federal District Court to enjoin the Attorney General of New Jersey and other New Jersey officials from proceeding with the prosecution of an indictment pending against him in that state.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We granted both petitions to consider the propriety of federal-court intervention in pending state criminal proceedings in the circumstances presented by this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in the written opinion filed today, we hold that the Court of Appeals properly affirmed the District Court's dismissal of Helfant's prayer for a permanent injunction but that the Appellate Court was in error in ordering a hearing and declaratory judgment on the issue of the admissibility of his grand jury testimony in a state criminal prosecution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is vacated and the case is remanded to that court with directions to enter a judgment affirming the District Court's dismissal of the complaint.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.text: And Mr. Justice Brennan took no part in its decision.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: It is hard to imagine if we were planning a new kind of procedure we perhaps would say the tax were what to have jurisdiction of excise tax cases.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: But Congress has quite plainly said that court is only to have jurisdiction over income state and gift taxes.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Congress could have decided the other way and given the tax code jurisdiction over those cases once having decided the other way, the Commissioner has more or less dealt himself bound by that congressional decisions and has refrain consistently from assuming those of efficiency with respect to these cases.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: But I retain to the question Mr. Justice Blackmun asked.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In what way would the Government be prejudiced if the Court Of Appeals of the Sixth Circuit reading blending these two statutes together where construed by the Commissioner to be the correct interpretation?

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Well I don't think the Government you know it is hard to imagine how you know the Government would be prejudiced other than the fact that you know because of the Commissioner's consistent policy perhaps some $100 million of assessments that we point out in our petition and the Hall case would be endangered.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: And if these cases can go to the District Court as we submit I think Judge Kaufman's concerns and I think the concerns of Judge Brown articulated in the Clark versus Campbell opinion which this Court is holding on our petition vanish.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Once you recognize that the taxpayers can go in the District Court to this rapid remedy of a refund suit I don't think that there are any significant constitutional problems.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: My remaining time I would like to talk a little bit about this statutory history because I think that it sheds important light on the congressional decision not to give the Tax Court jurisdiction over these cases. Now --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: You haven't forgotten your assurance to Mr. Justice Blackmun again, so?

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Yes perhaps I would have just briefly tell Mr. Justice Blackmun and the Court as to the basis to be assessment in the Hall case.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Now with respect to Mrs. Hall, the Commissioner terminated her taxable year as of the end of January 1973.

context.text: When the suit is filed for the redetermination of the deficiency assume they sold the Volkswagen and there's $51,000.00 sill owed when she files the suit that prevents the IRS from then trying to collect the other $51,000.00 until the deficiency has been redetermined and this is the protection.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Even though the IRS feels that the collection is in jeopardy.

context.speaker: Donald M. Heavrin
context.text: Yes Mr. Justice Blackmun because again this is, this is a really a tricky constitutional problem the due process calls as right here between the taxpayer and the Government and the Government clearly, to illustrate the absurdity, go ahead sir.

context.text: I don't mean to interrupt your replenish but I thought your argument are the one that which Mr. Justice Blackmun acquitted, you're arguing as a statutory matter that the property should be returned -- that the distraint should be relieved.

context.text: Well, let  I may have interrupted Mr. Justice Blackmun let me make this observation to you.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I think you probably sense during Mr. Smith's argument a feeling on the part of several members of the Court that if the revenue is more than jeopardy and all we were talking about was a notice of deficiency in a fairly close legal question, if the Government wasn't prejudice and the taxpayer would be denied and after they litigate, there was some reason on the close case to resolve that in favor of the taxpayer.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But now you're in effect arguing that the revenues will be in jeopardy that this man who had $300,000.00 in this suitcase or in the engine compartment will just be free to leave the country until his tax determination is finally determined that was the equities in quite a different position.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And what about as expressed in the statutes?

context.speaker: Douglas A. Eldridge
context.text: As expressed in the statutes and in this -- in the Social Security Act, there is an extensive scheme, the NOLEO scheme set out to achieve support for AFDC children and parents.

context.speaker: Douglas A. Eldridge
context.text: But in that scheme, there is no condition of eligibility.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, what about Justice Brennan's question, let's assume this regulation is valid?

context.text: The Amendment?

context.text: The amendment --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of 73-1016, Lascaris against Shirley and 73-1095, Lavine against Shirley will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, a three-judge District Court in New York held invalid a New York statute that required the recipient of welfare benefits to cooperate in a paternity or support action against an absent parent as a condition of eligibility for benefits under the program for Aid to Families with Dependent Children.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The ground of the decision was that the New York statute was in conflict with the eligibility requirements of the federal statute.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Since that case was decided below, Congress has amended the federal statute effective the coming July which now makes ineligible for benefits any recipient who refuses to cooperate to compel the absent parent to contribute to the support of the child.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Therefore, although we agree with the three-judge court that the New York statute was invalid for the reason given by the three-judge court and therefore affirm its judgment.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In light of the new statute we have no occasion to prepare an extended opinion.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissented.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Since that case was decided below, Congress has amended the federal statute effective the coming July which now makes ineligible for benefits any recipient who refuses to cooperate to compel the absent parent to contribute to the support of the child.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: Precisely.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: While there never may have been the case and whatever the reason the New York legislation want to do it that that if the -- one plead guilty wants to do it he may take the suppression issue on appeal with the appellate court, is that it?

context.speaker: Robert S. Hammer
context.text: Precisely Your Honor.

context.text: Did you want to answer Mr. Justice Brennan further?

context.text: I answered him Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1627, Lefkowitz against Newsome will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by way of writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: A New York statute permits a defendant in a criminal case to plead guilty without forfeiting his right to appellate judicial review of certain constitutional claims including the claim that evidence supporting the criminal charge was obtained by the state in a search procedure that violated the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: At the behest of the petitioner, Louis Lefkowitz who is the Attorney General of the State of New York, we granted certiorari to consider his claim that federal habeas corpus relief is not available under the circumstances of this case because of the plea of guilty.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out on the written opinion of the Court filed today with the clerk, we hold that when a state law permits a defendant to plead guilty without forfeiting his right to judicial review of specified constitutional issues, the defendant is not foreclosed from pursuing those constitutional claims in a federal habeas corpus proceeding after he has exhausted his state remedies.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has also filed a dissenting opinion which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have also joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: At the behest of the petitioner, Louis Lefkowitz who is the Attorney General of the State of New York, we granted certiorari to consider his claim that federal habeas corpus relief is not available under the circumstances of this case because of the plea of guilty.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out on the written opinion of the Court filed today with the clerk, we hold that when a state law permits a defendant to plead guilty without forfeiting his right to judicial review of specified constitutional issues, the defendant is not foreclosed from pursuing those constitutional claims in a federal habeas corpus proceeding after he has exhausted his state remedies.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has also filed a dissenting opinion which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have also joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company.speaker: Justice Burger
Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company.case_name: Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company v. National Labor Relations Board
Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 23, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas will also announce the judgment -- opinion of the Court in 73-1231 and 1234, Linden Lumber Division against the Labor Board and the related case.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: These cases involve a question of elections under the National Labor Relations Act of when -- who has the obligation of going forward after an impasse has been reached.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In this case, the employer was not guilty of any unfair labor practice, entered into no agreement to settle it by means other than the election conducted by the board and there was a dispute as to whether or not the union represented the employees that it purported to represent.

Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company.speaker: Justice Douglas
Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company.case_name: Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company v. National Labor Relations Board
Linden Lumber Division, Summer & Company.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 23, 1974

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In this case, the employer was not guilty of any unfair labor practice, entered into no agreement to settle it by means other than the election conducted by the board and there was a dispute as to whether or not the union represented the employees that it purported to represent.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: We conclude that within the statutory system as we read it, at that junction the duty was on the labor union to ask for the board's action to invoke the power of the board to conduct an election.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Our reasons are elaborated in an opinion filed with the clerk.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice White, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Powell joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: Joe B. Dibrell, Jr.
context.text: Really, what the respondent is here and what we are seeking and urging upon this Court is some validation of the tools to the trial judges to compel the art of proceedings of the maters before them.

context.speaker: Joe B. Dibrell, Jr.
context.text: I think it's respondent's really petition-- contention here that it is the judge and not the lawyer who must be the final arbiter of such matters and, as to the suppression of evidence or claim of privilege subject for review, as the trial proceeding can go on in due course.

context.speaker: Joe B. Dibrell, Jr.
context.text: And, I readily admit that the conduct of counsel here was not contumacious, but I think it is clear that it was contemptuous in the sense that it did actually counsel a disobedience of a trial judge's order for production of these matters.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, what if that order had been directed, as I think as Mr. Justice White suggested, to a question subpoenaed to the witness while he was on the stand in the course of trial and he declined to answer on the ground the response might tend to incriminate him.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would you think the lawyer could be held in contempt for so-advising him?

context.speaker: Joe B. Dibrell, Jr.
context.text: No, Your Honor, not until such time as the judge specifically says you go ahead and answer the question and then, if the lawyer persists in telling it, I think at that point it's the witness' determination to make that determination whether he wants to be held in contempt, go ahead and suffer the consequences for being held in contempt or--

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I have the judgment and opinion of the Court to announce in No. 73-689, Maness against Meyers.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And for reasons stated in an opinion filed today, the judgment of the judicial District Court of Bell County, Texas is reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart with whom Mr. Justice Blackmun joined filed an opinion concurring in the result and Mr. Justice White filed an opinion, a separate opinion concurring in the result.

context.speaker: Bruce S. Rogow
context.text: My impression form your opinion Mr. Justice Rehnquist, is that you certainly found that there was much testimony in the Congressional hearings that there had been abuses and people were entering into sham marriages.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, that factor was there but I think it was dealt with fairly shortly in the legislative history.

context.speaker: Bruce S. Rogow
context.text: But no matter how long it was, there was a legislative history that showed there were abuses and Congress was seeking to protect the system against those abuses.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do you disagree then with the import of Mr. Justice Stewart's question in the earlier case that, that test is  is there any conceivable set of facts that would support this distinction? You say that Congress must have manifested its concern.

context.speaker: Bruce S. Rogow
context.text: I say that because in every case, the Court has looked to see if there is some way to conclude that Congress had some concern.

context.speaker: Bruce S. Rogow
context.text: I am not saying that Congress must have manifested it by coming out with a long preamble to a statute which says this is why we did it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinions of the Court in two cases, 73-1046, Matthews against Diaz and 73-1596, Hampton against Mow Sun Wong will each be announced by Mr. Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In 73-1046, the case involves a challenge to the constitutionality of a portion of the Social Security Act, which makes resident aliens who are over 65, ineligible for participation in a medical insurance program unless they have been admitted for permanent residence and also have resided in the United States for at least five years.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: A Three-Judge District Court sitting in the Southern District of Florida, held the statue unconstitutional.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion in No. 73-1346, McLucas against DeChamplain will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the United States District Court for the District of Columbia.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Appellee, an Air Force Master Sergeant was charged with unauthorized use of classified military documents in violation of 134 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Our recent decision in Schlesinger against Councilman also disposes of appellee's claim with respect to access by his civilian counsel to the classified documents.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: As we said in Schlesinger, when a serviceman is charged with crimes by military authorities and can show no harm other than that attended upon resolution of his case within in the military court system, the Federal District Courts must refrain from intervention.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We accordingly vacate the injunction and remand the case to the District Court.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in which Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Powell.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1765, Meek versus Pittenger along with 74-363, United States against Reliable Transfer Company will each be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The first of these cases, Meek against Pittenger is here on direct appeal from a three-judge United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In this case we are required to determined once again whether a state law providing assistance to non-public church related elementary and secondary schools is constitutional under the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment made applicable to the states by the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The three-judge District Court in this case unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the textbook loan program authorized by Act 195.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: By a divided vote, the Court also upheld the constitutionality of Act 194's provision of auxiliary services to children in non-public elementary and secondary schools and Act 195's authorization of loans of instructional material directly to non-public elementary and secondary schools.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons stated in the written opinion of the Court filed today, we reverse the judgment of the District Court relating to auxiliary services and instructional materials and equipment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons stated in the relevant part of the opinion to which Mr. Justice Blackmun, Mr. Justice Powell, and I have subscribed, coupled with the reasons stated in Mr. Justice Rehnquist's separate opinion which Mr. Justice White has joined and supported in a separate opinion filed by the Chief Justice, we affirm the judgment of the District Court relating to textbooks.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: Whatever you call it, whatever nomenclature, it is a decision by the court, a Military Court, in which, upon conviction, the man loses his liberty just as the civilian indigent under this Court's ruling in Argersinger loses his liberty.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: Whether it be for a moment, an hour, or a day, the result is the same.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: The question--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Okay, go down a notch on the scale that -- what was in my days, now we call it company punishment, and I take it Justice Stewart's reference is to some sort of an investigative thing like that, which you say you're not complaining about, where you can have conditions of closed confinement and supervision.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: There, the company commander simply investigates.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You're there, he probably asks you your side of the story, and what he ends up doing is frequently confining you to the post or something like that.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: Now, somebody has to prosecute that case against the accused.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: We certainly can't expect that the accused will be serving as the prosecutor against himself.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: Somebody has to be acting as prosecutor and, obviously, by the very regulations of the Manual of Courts-Martial, that is the man who is also serving as judge, the man who will find whether or not the accused is guilty or innocent.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Zahm, I find your reference to the -- certainly, the First Circuit supports what you say but, it seems to me, that disregards the whole Courts of civil law adjudication which we couldn't have in this country in criminal cases because of the guarantee of jury trial, but your judge (Inaudible) in your French Courts and the typical civil law is just what Justice Powell says it is.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It's an inquiring magistrate who is supposed to find out the truth and, whereas, you couldn't have it in civil proceedings here because of the jury trial guarantees.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I'm not persuaded that you've carried any burden of showing it's basically unfair, which you have to under the Due Process Clause.
But if you are not a lawyer, -- But if you want a lawyer you can get it.

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: You can get it at the risk of greater punishment which this Court in United States versus Jackson says  is an unconstitutional limitation on your use of your Constitutional rights.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But in the other situation, if you want a jury, you can get it, but you have to expose your self to greater punishment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: Nathan R. Zahm
context.text: In the two-tier example, as I understand it, you may have the jury trial in the first trial as a matter of fact.
You did not get a jury trial the first tier court, and I do not think.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 74-175, Secretary of the Navy against Henry and 74-5176, Henry against the Secretary of the Navy will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The question in these cases which come to us from the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit is whether there is a right to counsel in summary court-martial proceedings in the armed forces.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We conclude that neither the Sixth Amendment nor Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment required counsel in such proceedings.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Furthermore, unlike a civilian trail, it is not like an adversary proceeding where counsel is required to counter an opposing advocate.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We also hold that the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment imposes no requirement of counsel in such proceedings.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on the appeal of the plaintiffs is affirmed and the appeal of the federal parties is reversed.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1924, Muniz against Hoffman, Regional Director of the Labor Board, would be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Petitioner Muniz and a labor union local were tried and convicted of criminal contempt, their offense being the violation of an injunction issued under Section 10(l) of the Labor Management Relations Act at the behest of the board's regional director.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Muniz was placed on probation and the union was fined $10,000.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed, rejecting petitioners' claims that they were wrongfully denied jury trial under Section 3692 of the Criminal Code which provides for jury trial in contempt actions arising out of labor disputes and under the Sixth Amendment which guarantees jury trial in all criminal cases.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We granted the petition for certiorari and now affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals in all respects.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Judgment of Court of Appeals represents the overwhelming view in the circuits and for the reasons stated in an opinion on filed with the clerk we agree with it.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed the dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I have also filed a dissenting opinion in this case in which I have been joined by Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In 1948, Congress repealed Section 11 of the Norris-LaGuardia Act, which provided a right to a jury trial in cases of contempt arising under that Act, and added another section to Title 18 of the United States Code, which broadly guarantees a jury trial, "in all cases of contempt arising under the laws of the United States governing the issuance of injunctions or restraining orders in any case involving or growing out of a labor dispute."

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We granted the petition for certiorari and now affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals in all respects.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Judgment of Court of Appeals represents the overwhelming view in the circuits and for the reasons stated in an opinion on filed with the clerk we agree with it.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed the dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In 1948, Congress repealed Section 11 of the Norris-LaGuardia Act, which provided a right to a jury trial in cases of contempt arising under that Act, and added another section to Title 18 of the United States Code, which broadly guarantees a jury trial, "in all cases of contempt arising under the laws of the United States governing the issuance of injunctions or restraining orders in any case involving or growing out of a labor dispute."

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell and I cannot agree with the Court's conclusion that this congressional action was without any significance and that section added in 1948 does not apply to any contempt proceedings involving injunctions that may be issued pursuant to the National Labor Relations Act.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 74-5116, Murphy against Florida will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Petitioner, who was convicted in a state court of robbery, sought a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that he had been denied a fair trial because jurors had learned from news accounts of his prior felony convictions or certain facts about the robbery charge itself.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Looking to the particular facts of this case, we hold that the jurors did not display hostility to petitioner, suggesting a partiality that could not be set aside.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The jurors neither betrayed or belief in the relevance on petitioner's past through his present guilt nor withdrawn from a community with settlements so inflamed against petitioner as to call in to question various signs of impartiality.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit denying the writ is affirmed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed an opinion concurring in the result and Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1316, Renegotiation Board against Grumman and 73-1233, Labor Board against Sears will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The issue in the Sears case, 73-1233 is whether the Freedom of Information Act requires a disclosure upon request of certain documents known as Advice and Appeals Memoranda generated by the office of General Counsels of the National Labor Relations Board in the course of deciding whether or not to permit the filing with the Board of an unfair labor practice complaint.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit held that the disclosure was required.

National Labor Relations Board v. Sears,.speaker: Justice White
National Labor Relations Board v. Sears,.case_name: National Labor Relations Board v. Sears, Roebuck & Company
National Labor Relations Board v. Sears,.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 28, 1975

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We affirm insofar as the documents conclude that a complaint should not be filed but reversed where the conclusion is that the complaint should issue.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Our reasons for these conclusions are given in an opinion on file with the clerk.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Chief Justice concurs in the result.

context.speaker: Byron R. White

National League of Cities v. Usery.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
National League of Cities v. Usery.case_name: National League of Cities v. Usery
National League of Cities v. Usery.title: ORAL REARGUMENT - MARCH 02, 1976

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: I am sorry Mr. Justice Powell, I was trying to say that when you are dealing with pay levels, that type of statute in which obviously Federalism could be destroyed by a minimum wage which said $30 per hour for state employees or could be destroyed be a statute which said, You may pay no state employee more than $4000 a year.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: Obviously those things would destroy statutes.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: But if you use a no discrimination rule, the Federal government without destroying itself can never destroy Federalism.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The decision that Justice Frankfurter took in New York against United States and I think that majority of the court felt that something more was required and just delayed laying down a no discrimination rule in order to protect the state.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: I think the taxing field is somewhat different than this field Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: And it would be -- I think it is different for a variety of reasons.

National League of Cities v. Usery.speaker: Justice Powell
National League of Cities v. Usery.case_name: National League of Cities v. Usery
National League of Cities v. Usery.title: ORAL REARGUMENT - MARCH 02, 1976

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: No Mr. Justice Powell, I trust I have not suggested homogenizing the country.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: (Inaudible) towards that --

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: Well of course every exercise of the commerce power is a step towards the obliteration of Federalism.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: I understand that, but I come back to Justice Rehnquist's distinction.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case, arguably, is different.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: I realize you have a different view but I say arguably, this is the first major intrusion starting with West that I know of, in which the Federal government is saying to the states and localities, We are going to run your labor policies and fix your wages and salaries, that is a major departure as I view it.

National League of Cities v. Usery.speaker: Justice Burger
National League of Cities v. Usery.case_name: National League of Cities v. Usery
National League of Cities v. Usery.title: ORAL REARGUMENT - MARCH 02, 1976

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: Only I think in the sense that the Tenth Amendment conforms the implication to be drawn from two other things.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: One is the implication to be drawn from the fact that powers are enumerated and therefore, in some sense, limited.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: And the other is the fact that the document that constitution specifies dual sets of governments and to that extent, specifies that there is Federalist value written in the document, just as they would have been I think, the constitution protection for free political speech there had never been a First Amendment.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Do you think that the Tenth Amendment has any functions such as the First Amendment has on the commerce power in Justice Stewart's hypothetical?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: Well if it does, one could say that the Federalist value is located in the Tenth Amendment, but I think it is located elsewhere at the Tenth Amendment is just as true as just in this court said in Darby.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: But if it is located in the Tenth Amendment, then it is certainly not true that this case is different from Darby because the Tenth Amendment explicitly says, The rights are reserved to the states and to the people if not delegated to the Congress.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has three opinions to announce, National League of Cities against Usery, Aldinger against Howard, and United States against Santana.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In National League of Cities against Usery, the case arises out of suits brought in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia by appellants National League of Cities and towns, the State of California and individual cities and towns against respondent Secretary of Labor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Appellants sought to enjoin the enforcement of parts of the 1974 Amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act.

National League of Cities v. Usery.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
National League of Cities v. Usery.case_name: National League of Cities v. Usery
National League of Cities v. Usery.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 24, 1976

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: After mature and careful consideration, as we are capable of giving the matter, we have decided that Maryland against Wirtz was wrongly decided, and we now overrule it.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We hold that Congress is prohibited by traditional principles of inter-governmental immunity embodied in the Constitution from using its commerce power to impose minimum wage and maximum hour requirements on employees of state and local governments who were engaged in the carrying out of integral government functions or the furnishing of traditional governmental services.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We accordingly, reverse the judgment of the District Court and remand the case to it for further proceedings and conformity with the opinion filed today with the clerk.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun has filed a separate concurring opinion; Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall joined; Mr. Justice Stevens has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren N. Coppedge, Jr.
context.text: I am claiming that we can be bludgeoned economically by interrupting the commercial course of business.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But if the judge - if the creditor went to a Judge with a piece of paper and swore before the Judge of these facts and the Judge thought that gave a probable clause at least pending some further hearings you wouldn't have any objection?

context.speaker: Warren N. Coppedge, Jr.
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What the Board has done is a different division of clerk here and a Judge in the case posited by Justice White.

context.speaker: Warren N. Coppedge, Jr.
context.text: We think that is one of the basic reasons.

context.speaker: Warren N. Coppedge, Jr.
context.text: The other is the fact that it's issued upon conclusory allegations without saying anything.

North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem.speaker: Justice Burger

North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 22, 1975

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1121, North Georgia Finishing Company against Di-Chem, Incorporated will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This is an appeal from the decision of the Georgia Supreme Court sustaining the Georgia prejudgment garnishment statute.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That law permits a creditor suing his debtor to attach and put beyond use during the litigation certain property of the debtor in the hands of third persons.

North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem.speaker: Justice White
North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem.case_name: North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem, Inc.
North Georgia Finishing, Inc. v. Di-Chem.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 22, 1975

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: As explained in the opinion filed today, it is the Court's view that Georgia statute is invalid under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That the Georgia Supreme Court failed to take account of this Court's decision in Fuentes against Shevin in 407 U.S. and that the later decision in Mitchell against Grant does not save the Georgia procedure.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment below is reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a concurring statement.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Rehnquist has joined and in paragraph 5 of which the Chief Justice joins.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But first, did the Solicitor General say a constitutional right?

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: Yes Your Honor.

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: Yes he does.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And did he take into account the language of the charged that has to do with -- I've forgotten the precise words, Mr. Justice White focused on a few moments ago, all treatment, not treatment that's available, you are instructed that person who is involuntarily, civilly committed does have a constitutional right to receive such treatment as you will give him as will give him a realistic opportunity to be cured.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now, does that take into account that instruction that there may be no treatment then known that will give a realistic opportunity?

context.speaker: Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
context.text: Yes it does Your Honor.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 74-8, O'Connor against Donaldson will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by way of a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The respondent, Kenneth Donaldson, was civilly committed to confinement as a mental patient in the Florida State Hospital at Chattahoochee in 1957.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That decision was in the case of Wood against Strickland decided earlier this term.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, we vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case to enable that court to consider, in the light of Wood against Strickland, whether the District Judge's failure to instruct with regard to the effect of O'Connor's claimed reliance on state law rendered inadequate the instructions as to O'Connor's liability for compensatory and punitive money damages.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Chief Justice, while joining the opinion of the Court has filed a separate concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The Court will be in recess from today until Monday, the 30th of June at which time we will adjourn for the term unless otherwise ordered at that time.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. McKeen, are you saying something like this that you're familiar with the differences among us of this Court on the question of the constitutionality of obscenity laws?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: There are members of this Court who think that no obscenity law is constitutional that it violates the First Amendment and there are others who think there're maybe within certain limits constitutionality of obscenity laws.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now, suppose you had a prosecution under the obscenity and there were conviction and it was within the scope of the principle as this Court has stated that are permissible to a state but your Supreme Court would to say, I don't agree within majority of the Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We agree with Mr. Justice Douglas that no obscenity law is constitutional under the federal constitution and with the reverse the conviction on that ground.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Are you suggesting that that would be conclusive on the State of Oregon because that was a holding of your Supreme Court it interpreted the federal constitution.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Has it thought, it ought to be rather than the way this Court had?

context.speaker: Sam A. McKeen
context.text: Well, Cooper versus California says -- now, this was Cooper versus California was searched where the state had a statute also and the Supreme Court considered the case only as to whether or not the search was reasonable under the federal constitution.

context.speaker: Sam A. McKeen
context.text: And they said the state is free if it chooses to do so without review by us to apply its own state's harmless error rule to set areas of state law.

context.speaker: Sam A. McKeen
context.text: They're being no federal constitutional area here, there's no need for us to determine this matter and that's --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Your response about reading the constitution -- federal constitution more expansively then the -- it's read up here would bring you right against the proposition Mr. Justice White suggested to you that if that reading then imposed a liability on a police officer for damages for violating the Fourth Amendment or any other provision in a way that we did not countenance then you I thought did say that the officer would have a claim that his rights under the federal constitution have been violated because he regarded and have been talked to regard this United States Constitution as the supreme law of the land.

context.speaker: Sam A. McKeen
context.text: Well, that still Your Honor is the way that I would think it would be if I can follow the thread of the fact situation correctly.

context.speaker: Sam A. McKeen
context.text: The officer has his citizen of United States under the federal constitution he would have a right to have done what he did and therefore his constitutional rights have been violated by damages and he should have proper standing before this Court.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Supreme Court of Oregon affirmed by a sharply divided four-to-three vote.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And it did show, we hold and solely on federal constitutional grounds.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today, we reverse the Supreme Court of Oregon and hold that this case despite its slight factual differences is controlled by our decision in Harris against New York.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And I'm authorized to say that Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion and is joined therein by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has also filed a separate dissenting opinion and is joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
