context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-375, Otte against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case raises issues concerning withholding taxes in the bankruptcy context.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We took certiorari from the Second Circuit because the Federal Courts of Appeals were in disagreement on the primary issue.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We refuse to place them in the fourth category because they are not taxes that became legally due and owing by the bankrupt.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And we do not place them in the first priority relating to cost and expenses of administration.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 74-121, Phelps against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan along with the disposition of 74-453, Van Lare against Hurley, and 74-5054, Taylor against Lavine.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: 74-121 is here from the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: A corporate taxpayer unable to pay assessed federal taxes conveyed its assets to an assignee for the benefit of creditors.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: How did you come here now because it's not an issue which requires to be heard by a three-judge -- even if the three-judge court decides?

context.speaker: William L. Patton, Jr.
context.text: It is not an issue that's require to be hear by the three-judge court but the three-judge court can hear it if --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But why -- how does that make it appealable here merely because the three-judge court is if it's not in Constitution.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Don't you have to argue in response to Justice Brennan the Supremacy Clause determination is the constitutional determination for purposes of our appellate jurisdiction?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But we believe we get to that.

context.speaker: William L. Patton, Jr.
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: White against William?

context.speaker: William L. Patton, Jr.
context.text: Well, it may have been rejected but then in Hagans against Lavine, I thought that it was again reconsidered though not adopted.

context.speaker: William L. Patton, Jr.
context.text: At least --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I thought they can provide it for Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: With seven pages from 536 to 543 -- they live up to that.

context.speaker: William L. Patton, Jr.
context.text: No no, I don't suggest Hagans against Lavine resolves the question.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1820, Philbrook against Glodgett and a companion case 74-132, Weinberger against Glodgett and the judgement and opinion in 74-124, Blue Chip Stamps against Manor Drug Stores will each be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Philbrook against and Glodgett and Weinberger against Glodgett the question is whether the receipt of State unemployment compensation may be permitted to bar the receipt of aid -- aid for dependent children assistance under the federal Social Security statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: A three-judge District Court in Vermont held that it could not be and that Vermont's administration of its program so as to terminate AFDC upon receipt of -- or eligibility for unemployment compensation violated the applicable federal statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Even though in my hypothesis certainly the man is subjected to sort of constraints that you say amount to a restriction on his liberty?

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: That's right Your Honor and we say that even when that loss is present in terms of a procedural Due Process right it would not exist because it would be meaningless that the court specifically stated both of the lower courts stated that unless that the transfer is based on some evaluation about the individual himself.

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: So, that the individual could contribute something of value to a due process hearing; the case is not applicable.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let me alter Mr. Justice Rehnquist's hypothetical case just to trifle perhaps not to trifle.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: A decision is made administratively by the Director of the Institutions for the state that 500 prisoners from one category or let us say medium security must be transferred to other facilities, and the only other ones available are maximum security and the warden in each institution has then directed to determine which of the prisoners in his institution are marginally more dangerous, more in need of maximum security than others.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now, he's got to make a value of judgment to effect that transfer in order to relieve the overcrowding, a due process hearing?

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: So that --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, they do required vested interest --

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: -- then you answered correctly even under your theory to Mr. Justice Powell and I was mistaken about your theory?

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: I see, we believe that both interests were an inmate would be deprive to both interest by a move from Wallkill to maximum security institution that the liberty interest is more direct in terms of looking at the differences between Wallkill and Clinton but that it also acquired a state created benefit that he had reasonable expectation of maintaining that benefit until he's released from prison because that is the usual procedures that Wallkill that prison stayed there until release and very few people are transferred back.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, the transfer from Wallkill to Clinton because of overcrowding that I asked you about earlier would I would think deprive him of that property interest if he has one.

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: The hearing is to decide what the facts are and what the attitude of the inmate is?

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: What mitigations serve necessary?

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: But of course the final decision is still left the prison administrators as it properly should and the same exact situation exists in this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: It seems to me when you answered Mr. Justice White you added another factor the complaint being critical.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You said if the institution has a rule that six violations leads to transfer then they could do it without an additional hearing.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice White didn't begin with the premise that there was an institutional rule but that the warden and the process of evaluating all prisoners who had had problems said here's the man with six violations we think he's got to go somewhere else.

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: But of course the final decision is still left the prison administrators as it properly should and the same exact situation exists in this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: It seems to me when you answered Mr. Justice White you added another factor the complaint being critical.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You said if the institution has a rule that six violations leads to transfer then they could do it without an additional hearing.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice White didn't begin with the premise that there was an institutional rule but that the warden and the process of evaluating all prisoners who had had problems said here's the man with six violations we think he's got to go somewhere else.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now, there's no rule this is just a value in judgment that six is enough for this man and it might take into account the nature of the crime which he committed in the first place, the length of the sentence which he had long or short.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What do you say about that must there be a hearing for that?

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: No, in fact, in this case the court below found that in spite of Mr. Newkirk's actions that he had done nothing that he had perfectly -- that he had adjusted well to Wallkill and was participating fully and never been any problem, and in spite of the fact that they had made a mistake about what they claimed required the transfer.

context.speaker: Daniel Pochoda
context.text: He was still transferred and of course this can happen today and tomorrow as well.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: That was a little puzzle by one of your responses.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You suggested I think in answer from Mr. Justice Stewart that if they decided that the last 300 prisoners in would be the ones transferred.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Or the first 300 in just an arbitrary classification but that would be all right.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now, is there any rational basis for that or what is the rational basis for that (Voice Overlap)?

context.speaker: Hillel Hoffman
context.text: And under the rational of the Second Circuit where due process is measured only by the loss experience by the inmate and I think legally we would be required to give hearings in this situation.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Under the prison rules or do the prison rules expressly say that for certain kinds of conduct a transfer is inappropriate sanction?

context.speaker: Hillel Hoffman
context.text: No, they don't as a matter of fact the Court of Appeals struck out that requirement in the District Court's order because the Court of Appeals believed that it would be impossible to specify all of these situations that might lead to a transfer.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, Justice White's question was about the prison rule it's not about the District Court judgment.

context.speaker: Hillel Hoffman
context.text: No, there's nothing in the prison rules.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Were there or was there ever?

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in the Regional Rail Reorganization Act Cases, 74-165 and the related cases, will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: These are three appeals and a cross-appeal from a judgment of a three-judge District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania that declared unconstitutional the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973 and enjoined its enforcement.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The ground of the decision was that the Rail Act would affect a taking for public use without just compensation of the rail properties of the bankrupt Penn-Central Railroad because the Rail Act precluded a suit against the United States in the Court of Claims under the Tucker Act for a cash award in the amount of any shortfall from the constitutional minimum in the securities provided by the Rail Act to be paid for the rail properties.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The ground of the decision was that the Rail Act would affect a taking for public use without just compensation of the rail properties of the bankrupt Penn-Central Railroad because the Rail Act precluded a suit against the United States in the Court of Claims under the Tucker Act for a cash award in the amount of any shortfall from the constitutional minimum in the securities provided by the Rail Act to be paid for the rail properties.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, but that's all been bypassed here.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There is no probable about credibility here as you conceded that your clients got in by falsely representing that they were American citizens?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In the words of my Brother Stewart making a similar oral announcement several weeks ago, the Court's opinion in itself does lend itself to any detailed summary.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: For reasons set forth and some detail in the opinion, we hold that the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was correct in holding that these aliens were deportable and that this case is not controlled by our prior decision in Immigration and Nationalization Service versus Errico.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit is accordingly affirmed.

context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now, which way do you think the time factor works again in relation to the Kiff case, as I recall it in the Kiff case the temporary injunction have been in effect for about three years, here it's a little bit over one year.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I would say yes your Honor, it's a year and five months.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I suppose I would have to stand by the First Amendment and take the view that even a day of a prior restrain is an assault which has to be justified by --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: As same question that Mr. Justice Rehnquist is passing to you, whether you have a final judgment in the Kiff case, I think the Court took on pains to say or indicate that temporary injunction having continued for three years that was reasonable, so that was quite permanent.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I think it is deeply reasonable to assume Mr. Chief Justice, then the light of the opinion on special term the unanimous decision of the appellate division, the unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals that it would be most unlikely are in the Court, rather this Court, to have dissolve the injunction before the case have gone its way.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: May I attend to what Mr. Justice Stewart's question or questions, let's assume for the moment that your clients on that day, patient's identity had been disclosed clearly unequivocal in this book, would you be here today in that situation?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I suppose I would have to stand by the First Amendment and take the view that even a day of a prior restrain is an assault which has to be justified by --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: As same question that Mr. Justice Rehnquist is passing to you, whether you have a final judgment in the Kiff case, I think the Court took on pains to say or indicate that temporary injunction having continued for three years that was reasonable, so that was quite permanent.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I think it is deeply reasonable to assume Mr. Chief Justice, then the light of the opinion on special term the unanimous decision of the appellate division, the unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals that it would be most unlikely are in the Court, rather this Court, to have dissolve the injunction before the case have gone its way.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: May I attend to what Mr. Justice Stewart's question or questions, let's assume for the moment that your clients on that day, patient's identity had been disclosed clearly unequivocal in this book, would you be here today in that situation?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I do not think I would be here today to answer your question Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In other words, it's a basis of your case, that as matter of fact the patient's identity was not revealed in this book?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: And such finding is there are they can be called findings run in petitioner's favor.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: But, it seems to me that there is a suggestions in that opinion that this intermingling of arguments and inferences and this absence of elucidated statements in fact, is precisely what makes difficult if not impossible the course of appellate review.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: And therefore, I think it's possible to read from that case in due process clause as to the views of this Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I wonder, back in response to Mr. Justice Stewart you indicated that under that thing and the attorneys example he gave that there state would have power who in such injunction, was that answer based on the reach of the confidential relationship that was inherit in Mr. Justice Stewart's questions or was it the nature of the disclosure, so that would be upon fully aside from whether they would have reach any confidential initiative?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I don't wish to be vague in answer to your question Mr. Justice White but all that I can say is that learning amicus representing the American Psychiatric Associations and two other world organizations have postulated five different possible theories of liability, and said that it's unclear which of them or which combinations of them would be involved.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, you gave-- you answered Mr. Justice Stewart however, I wondered what's basis was?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: And therefore, I think it's possible to read from that case in due process clause as to the views of this Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I wonder, back in response to Mr. Justice Stewart you indicated that under that thing and the attorneys example he gave that there state would have power who in such injunction, was that answer based on the reach of the confidential relationship that was inherit in Mr. Justice Stewart's questions or was it the nature of the disclosure, so that would be upon fully aside from whether they would have reach any confidential initiative?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I don't wish to be vague in answer to your question Mr. Justice White but all that I can say is that learning amicus representing the American Psychiatric Associations and two other world organizations have postulated five different possible theories of liability, and said that it's unclear which of them or which combinations of them would be involved.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, you gave-- you answered Mr. Justice Stewart however, I wondered what's basis was?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I would suppose that it would be possible for a State Court to formulate a standard of liability based on the breach of the confidential relationship between a professional person and someone coming to see the professional person, assuming that all of the standards have been met and that all of the procedural necessities have been met.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, if the state might assert a variety of interest or maybe the same interest expressed a variety of ways one like the breach for confidential relationship, another way of perhaps putting the same thing as the violation of an implied contract.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- it's a state cause of action under the state tort law, isn't it?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: But as -- that is the way the cause of actions is played Mr. Justice Stewart but to indicate the difficulties and attempting to comprehend what happened in the State Courts of New York.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: The decision which is cited by the appellate division is this Courts decisions in the abortion cases is suggesting that there is a merging constitutional right of privacy, how that can be read into this case is beyond me but there it is.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Was it suppose to little early to expect that read Mr. Justice Stewart's opinion in the case that came down this morning or perhaps you did --

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I was able to glance at it, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You read that during lunch hour.

context.speaker: Ephraim S. London
context.text: At page 14 of our brief to the Court of Appeals, we did discussed the section, we said the court must presume to any question, in fact in dispute, were resolved by the appellate division in favor of the respondent.

context.speaker: Ephraim S. London
context.text: And then cited civil practice law and rules 5612b.

context.speaker: Ephraim S. London
context.text: May I, by the way have the Court's permission to respond to some errors, misstatements of fact in the reply brief by the letter to this Court?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. London, before you leave that, I'm puzzled about your explanation of New York practice because I'm trying to agree with what I think is Mr. Justice White's view that the special term found the issue of disguising against you --

context.speaker: Ephraim S. London
context.text: I'm just trying to say you find it my favor.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well partially implied -- applied there was identification for perhaps with respect with anybody else.

context.speaker: Ephraim S. London
context.text: But there was the Giff case, the organization for Giff case, in which a preliminary injunction did in fact come before this Court, and the Court stated that it had jurisdiction, and we are not contesting the jurisdiction of the Court in this case.

context.speaker: Ephraim S. London
context.text: I understood--

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: How is it by stipulation either, isn't it?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: That doesn't mean the we can't as Justice Blackmun suggests that concludes that there is no jurisdiction -- it was not easy if you read the Giff case closely.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: It was not easy for the Court to find jurisdiction there.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And I think there were some indication of an almost abandonment by one party of any effort to challenge the temporary injunction.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let's assume that though, for all the assumption that the 25 witnesses said yes, I read this book and never heard about it before Mr. London asked me who he is.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: From a reading of that book I put these factors together and I identified this patient as Dr. X.

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: I assume that these witnesses would be subjective to cross examination of course, and I presume that the trial of the facts would have an opportunity to evaluate this --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: As Mr. Justice White has suggested presumably make some findings of fact and then we wouldn't engage in this extensive cross examination that both of you gentlemen to try to find out some of these things, would we, if we need to?

context.speaker: Marvin M. Karpatkin
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, I would say that your argument follows completely if this were not the case --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Question maybe

context.speaker: David N. Rosen
context.text: The Connecticut courts have not construed the statute to be -- have not addressed themselves of the constitutionality of the statute.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The court in Connecticut that will --

context.speaker: David N. Rosen
context.text: The Connecticut Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Pass on the statute which is with Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, how do you do it here as this particular case now stands?

context.speaker: David N. Rosen
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-300, Saxbe against Bustos together with 73-480, Cardona against Saxbe will be announced by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: These cases are here on certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia and involve the construction of a rather obscure provision of the Immigration and Nationality Act, pertains to its application to people who come over from Mexico or from Canada each day to work and return at night.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: And also to those who would come over from Mexico or Canada to work for a season, like in a fruit harvest or wheat harvest, and return at the end of the season.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: There was a conflict between the Ninth Circuit that held that seasonal and daily commuters were covered by the immigration provision of the Act.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: And a ruling of the court below in this case had held if all daily commuters were covered, the seasonal commuters were not covered and therefore the seasonal workers would have to get a certificate from the Secretary of Labor.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: We agreed with the Court of Appeals to the Ninth Circuit and we think that all -- both daily and seasonal commuters are immigrants covered by that provision of the Act.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Therefore we affirm in part and reverse in part the judgment of the Court of Appeals which Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall, and Mr. Justice Blackmun have joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: There was a conflict between the Ninth Circuit that held that seasonal and daily commuters were covered by the immigration provision of the Act.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: And a ruling of the court below in this case had held if all daily commuters were covered, the seasonal commuters were not covered and therefore the seasonal workers would have to get a certificate from the Secretary of Labor.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-776, Schlesinger against Ballard will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here on direct appeal from the United States District Court for the Southern District of California.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The appellee, Robert C. Ballard is a lieutenant in the United States Navy.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Under the constitution, the responsibility for determining how best our Armed Forces shall attend to that business rests with the Congress and with the President.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in the written opinion filed today with the clerk, we hold that in exercising its broad constitutional power, Congress has not violated the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment in this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment is reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-2055, Securities Investor Protection Corporation against Barbour will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case comes to us by writ of certiorari to the United States District Court -- United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Securities Investor Protection Corporation was established by Congress for the purpose of providing financial relief to the customers of failing broker dealers with whom they had left cash or securities on deposit.

Securities Investor Protection Corp. v..speaker: Justice Marshall
Securities Investor Protection Corp. v..case_name: Securities Investor Protection Corp. v. Barbour
Securities Investor Protection Corp. v..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 19, 1975

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In an opinion on file with the clerk today, we hold that the SEC's right of action is exclusive of the right claimed by the customers themselves.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Examination of the statutory allocation of functions among the SEC, makes changes, and the SIPC itself indicates that Congress did not intend to allow a self-interested customer to trigger the process by which a broker dealer is liquidated.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The judgment below is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.text: I have the judgment and opinion to announce in No. 73-1424, Serfass against the United States.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And for reasons stated in an opinion filed today with the clerk, the judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit is affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting statement.

context.speaker: James H. Reynolds
context.text: Well, the history of state court decisions in regards --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, this is Iowa you're talking about.

context.speaker: James H. Reynolds
context.text: Well, anyway we all have an Iowa right.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And you have a unique statute in Iowa you indicated to Justice Blackmun?

context.speaker: James H. Reynolds
context.text: Well, it's unique in regards to durational residency requirement but I don't think it therefore makes it anymore easy for the Supreme Court of Iowa to decide it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well then, how are the actions of other state courts with different statutes relevant to this issue?

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: Actually their time for appeal has expired, I don't that is any longer available to them.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But all of our questions were directed to their right to go to the Supreme Court of Iowa at that time, not now.

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: At that time, yes sir, I think they did certainly have that right.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And is your answer to Justice Marshall that the State of Iowa is perfectly willing to bypass the State Supreme Court and go into federal court?

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: The State of Iowa since in the last 10 years has done a great deal to liberalize its divorce laws.

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: We also would like to know where we stand.

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: You abandoned it below and you abandon it here?

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: As Justice White said as in fact doctrine that protects state interest of the State doesn't want to be protected, I guess we don't apply the doctrine?

context.speaker: Elizabeth A. Nolan
context.text: We did abandon it below.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Why from the point of view the State, isn't the decision of the Supreme Court of Iowa just as good as source of certainty as a decision of a three-judge federal court?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-762, Sosna against Iowa, and the judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1313, ITT against the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Union will each be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Sosna, the State of Iowa enacted a statute under which only persons who have resided in the state for one year may file a petition for divorce in Iowa's courts.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Appellant Sosna who had resided in Iowa for only a month unsuccessfully sought to obtain a divorce in the Iowa state court and thereafter she filed a class action in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Iowa challenging the constitutionality of the Iowa residency requirement for divorce.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: On the merits we hold that the Iowa statute is constitutional.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It furthers the state's quite legitimate interest in protecting its decrees against collateral attack and assures that those persons seeking to invoke the powers of the state courts have a reasonable attachment to the state.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore affirm the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall joined by Mr. Justice Brennan has also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It furthers the state's quite legitimate interest in protecting its decrees against collateral attack and assures that those persons seeking to invoke the powers of the state courts have a reasonable attachment to the state.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore affirm the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall joined by Mr. Justice Brennan has also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It furthers the state's quite legitimate interest in protecting its decrees against collateral attack and assures that those persons seeking to invoke the powers of the state courts have a reasonable attachment to the state.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore affirm the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall joined by Mr. Justice Brennan has also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: Well, I don't think that -- I think that the point is not suppression.

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: I think that the point is the basis of time which the decision is made and you do not want to permit municipal officials to make decisions upon -- under the -- which involved a heavy amount of content discrimination, because they do not like these particular ideas being advocated and any criteria which fosters that, it seems to me is bad under the decisions of this case.

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: In fact, I know of no case to the contrary in this Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What if an art gallery, to pursue Mr. Justice Rehnquist's thesis a moment, what if an art gallery -- public gallery had a fixed rule that no living artist could be exhibited?

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: I think the rule is valid, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: I would evoke to sustain it, because I don't see built into that the perpetual suppression of ideas, nor do I see that it works (Voice Overlap).

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Hell's a' poppin', and --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: That was before your time. (Laughter)

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: Maybe --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And before Justice Rehnquist's time too.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, that's not a very common thing in the drama and quite common in the world of drama?

context.speaker: Henry P. Monaghan
context.text: Well, it's beyond me, I must say I haven't seen it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You mean even assuming -- even assuming, is it your argument, even assuming the case might have to be reversed under pre-Miller and related cases, it doesn't have to be remanded because of the intervening decisions?

context.speaker: Randall L. Nelson
context.text: That would be a secondary position.

context.speaker: Randall L. Nelson
context.text: First of all we would take the position that because this conduct did occur, the public nudity and so forth and it is directed at conduct and not a Miller obscenity standards or any other obscenity standards relating to First Amendment freedoms that the case shouldn't be remanded at all or shouldn't even be considered.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In other words, you're standing first on the violation of the public nudity that the Justice Stewart alluded to earlier?

context.speaker: Randall L. Nelson
context.text: Yes, Your Honor, that's true.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Nelson, do you think your case is any better by the virtue of the fact that the petitioners sought a lease from a municipally-owned theater then if it were simply a question of him having obtained a lease in a private theater and the city seeking to ban the production?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1004, Southeastern Promotions against Conrad will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.text: This case comes to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The petitioner is a promoter of theatrical productions.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Those safeguards in several respects were lacking here and we therefore conclude that the action of the board violated the petitioner's First Amendment rights.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It is to be emphasized as we do in the opinion that this is a decision based on prior restraint procedure.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We make no judgment as to whether the musical is or is not obscene or as to whether the courts below applied an incorrect standard for the determination of the issue of obscenity.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: The gross receipts tax was permitted in Norton on transactions with which the in-state office of Norton had far less connection than the in-state sales of Standard had with its office through Martinson.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: The material to which you refer, Mr. Justice White in Norton is dictum -- it was not necessary to the conclusion of that case. In Norton, there were certain sales which were found not to be taxable.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: Those sales in which the in-state office played no role whatsoever except theoretically having available certain engineering advice.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Justice Goldberg cited in Norton as dictating a different result, the Court arrived at in Norton, Norton said not so in those cases in the McGoldrick type case is not controlling here. Now you can call that dictum if you want to.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: In any event, our case can be solidly based on either McGoldrick or on the actual findings in Norton.

context.speaker: Slade Gorton
context.text: It doesnt matter which or whether or not they are distinguishable because both of them are consistent with taxability in the case which we have here before you.

context.speaker: Kenneth L. Cornell
context.text: Where is the use?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So what do you think in this case?

context.speaker: Kenneth L. Cornell
context.text: I think since the use takes place in the State of Washington, the State of Washington could impose a use tax.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, Justice Brennan has a question for you Mr. Attorney General.

context.text: Here in your index.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1461, Stanton against Stanton will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us from the Supreme Court of the State of Utah.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The appellant and the appellee were married in 1951 and divorced in Utah in 1960.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today we reverse the judgment of the Supreme Court of Utah and remand the case for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold that in the context of child support, the age classification made by the statute denies equal protection.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We find nothing rational in the statutory distinction between males and females which when related to the divorce decree results in the husband's liability for support for the daughter only to age 18 but for the son to age 21.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to state that Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold that in the context of child support, the age classification made by the statute denies equal protection.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We find nothing rational in the statutory distinction between males and females which when related to the divorce decree results in the husband's liability for support for the daughter only to age 18 but for the son to age 21.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to state that Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Kendall L. Vick
context.text: Not directly on point.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The tip given sometime ago with respect to grand?

context.speaker: Kendall L. Vick
context.text: Yes it does give me some trouble especially the --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The plurality of Mr. Justice Marshall?

context.speaker: Kendall L. Vick
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Is there any allegation anywhere in this case that the jury commissioners or other state officials systematically sought to discourage or exclude the presence of women on juries anyway?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-5744, Taylor against Louisiana will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: This is a criminal case that comes here from the courts of Louisiana where the petitioner Taylor's conviction was affirmed by the Louisiana Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: At the time of the conviction the statutes of the state provided that women would not be called for jury service unless they had filed a written declaration in advance if they desire to be subject to jury service.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The consequence was that hardly any women were called to serve on the criminal case juries.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The issue here is whether this jury selection system comports with the Sixth and the Fourteenth Amendments to be -- to the constitution.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: For the reasons we state in the opinion on file with the clerk, we hold that it does not and we consequently reverse the conviction of petitioner Taylor.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Chief Justice concurs in the judgment Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The issue here is whether this jury selection system comports with the Sixth and the Fourteenth Amendments to be -- to the constitution.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: For the reasons we state in the opinion on file with the clerk, we hold that it does not and we consequently reverse the conviction of petitioner Taylor.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Chief Justice concurs in the judgment Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Walter L. Gerash
context.text: Yes, you have to --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And you say you must make out in your sworn statement you must have allegations in there that would entitle your relief?

context.speaker: Walter L. Gerash
context.text: You have to -- I would liken it a probable cause affidavit because --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Justice Rehnquist asked your colleague if that was so, it is so.

context.speaker: Walter L. Gerash
context.text: Well, I suppose I should be on this side and he should be on my side.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But then, your affidavit was insufficient?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: As I understand it, yes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What is that difference do you think?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: In part of this process of authorizing for appropriation.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well isn't that pretty usual of authorizing this as Mr. Justice Rehnquist says more than they may have eventually appropriate?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: I don't think it's usual to have a process in which you authorize for appropriation and then go to the allotment stage and the obligation stage and then appropriate, I may be quite if that's --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But the allotment stage is unique here in the budgetary process, isn't it relevant in the authorization or the appropriation?

Train v. City of New York.speaker: Justice White

Train v. City of New York.speaker: Justice Burger
Train v. City of New York.case_name: Train v. City of New York
Train v. City of New York.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1975

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1377, Train against the City of New York will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The 1972 Amendments to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act authorize the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to allot to the state up to the amount -- sums of money up to the amounts specified in the Act for the years covered by the provisions of the Act.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Those funds allotted thereafter become available for commitment for approved sewage treatment projects.

Train v. City of New York.speaker: Justice White
Train v. City of New York.case_name: Train v. City of New York
Train v. City of New York.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 18, 1975

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The issue in the case is whether the Administrator has the authority to postpone allotments or to allot to the states less than the total amounts authorized under the Act.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia held that the Administrator had no such discretion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: For the reasons that we given an opinion on file with the Court -- or on file with the clerk, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I'm authorized to say that Mr. Justice Douglas concurs in the result.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

Train v. Natural Resources Defense Counc.speaker: Justice Burger
Train v. Natural Resources Defense Counc.case_name: Train v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc.
Train v. Natural Resources Defense Counc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 16, 1975

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1742, Train Administrator against Natural Resources Defense Council will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case involves a construction of the Clean Air Act and comes to us from the Court of Appeals from the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Clean Air Act requires that each state adopt the plan for attaining and maintaining national standards for the quality of air within its borders.

Train v. Natural Resources Defense Counc.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Train v. Natural Resources Defense Counc.case_name: Train v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc.
Train v. Natural Resources Defense Counc.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 16, 1975

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: For reasons set out at length in the opinion, we concluded that variances may be granted under Section 110 (a) (3) of the Act which governs revisions of state plans if the plan nonetheless concludes to provide for the attainment and maintenance of national air quality standard.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This was the adoption of the regulation originally promulgated by the EPA, the Fifth Circuit set it aside.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Fifth Circuit was wrong in doing so and we reverse the Fifth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has noted his dissent.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1888, United States against Alaska will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, this case comes to us on certiorari from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The issue here is whether the lower portion of the various substantial body of water known as Cook Inlet on the Southern Coast of the State of Alaska constitutes the high seas or what is known as a historic bay subject to the jurisdiction of the State.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We review in turn the evidence of sovereignty exercise during the Russian period, the territorial period prior to the time Alaska became a state and the period since statehood.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We conclude that neither Russia's exercise of authority nor our Federal Government's enforcement of fishing and wild life regulations or Alaska's enforcement of fishing regulations was sufficient for this purpose.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And we review in particular, the factor of acquiescence by foreign nations and also the significance of Alaska's arrest of two Japanese fishing vessels in the Shelikof Strait in 1962 and the Japanese reaction to that incident.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to say Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have filed a joint statement to the effect that in their view, the findings of fact made by the District Court and adopted by the Court of Appeals were not clearly erroneous and therefore, they would affirm the judgment.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

United States v. American Building Maint.speaker: Justice Burger
United States v. American Building Maint.case_name: United States v. American Building Maintenance Industries
United States v. American Building Maint.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 24, 1975

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1689, United States against American Building Maintenance Industries will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In this case, we entertain an appeal from United States District Court for the Central District of California.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Government commence this civil antitrust action in that court contending that the appellee, American Building Maintenance Industries, had violated Section 7 of the Clayton Act by acquiring the stock of the J.E. Benton Management Corporation and by merging the Benton Maintenance Company into one of its wholly owned subsidiaries.

United States v. American Building Maint.speaker: Justice Stewart
United States v. American Building Maint.case_name: United States v. American Building Maintenance Industries
United States v. American Building Maint.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 24, 1975

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Following discovery proceedings and the submission of memoranda and affidavits by both parties, the District Court granted the appellee's motion for summary judgment, holding that there had been no violation of Section 7 of the Clayton Act because neither of the Benton companies was engaged in interstate commerce.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Government then brought this direct appeal here and we noted probable jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out on a written opinion of the Court, the judgement of the District Court is affirmed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment and at all but -- but one part of the Court's opinion.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion which Mr. Justice Brennan has joined and Mr. Justice Blackmun has also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Now, when you get the answer of Section 7602, the statute talks about four purposes for which a summons like this can be issued.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: It talks about the purpose of ascertaining the correctness of any return for making a return where none has been made for determining the liability of any person for any Internal Revenue tax or collecting any such liability.

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: Now, we think that the summons in this case plainly falls within the statutory purposes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: You may have answered Mr. Justice Stewart on this and if so I missed it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: If you didnt have 7601 would 7602 be enough to take care of your case?

context.speaker: Stuart A. Smith
context.text: We believe it would because we think that the summons that was issued in this case falls within the statutory purpose of Section 7602 alone.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: They have drop houses and near the border, they have scouts who go ahead and phone back and so on.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: It is possible for -- to evade the system, and that is not air tight.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, in some prior casement to try, don't recall which one, not Almeida-Sanchez, I think before that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There was reference to in occasion when this strict border search that Mr. Justice White alluded to was enforced for some period of time, resulted in diplomatic representations by the Mexican Government to the state department of the United States.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: I'm afraid I'm not familiar with that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Was that in the case -- you're not familiar with the case?

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In this case, the only reason for stopping respondent's car was that the occupants appeared to be of Mexican descent.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We agree with the Court of Appeals that this alone does not constitute reasonable grounds to believe that the occupants were in fact aliens.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we hold that the stop was illegal.

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: If there was no realistic possibility at all, if they were completely independent, I doubt it very much, but that's not this case.

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: That's not this case Mr. Justice because C&S itself had three subsidiaries in which it owned 90% or more of the stock which puts conceivably -- might have been competing with these banks.

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: We don't know.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But don't you have to know something about the market then in order to answer Justice White's question.

context.speaker: Friedman

context.speaker: Daniel B. Hodgson
context.text: Yes sir, the economics of it.

context.speaker: Daniel B. Hodgson
context.text: In this case I should say though that the record is clear, that there is very little movement.

context.speaker: Daniel B. Hodgson
context.text: There was very their little movement in sale to the stock in the critical period.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In a hypothetical bank what Mr. Justice Rehnquist I think asked you about the bank over in Birmingham closely set out on a plan to buy above the stock that's got available in anyone of these five banks, against the possibility that one day they might want to enter that market.

context.speaker: Daniel B. Hodgson
context.text: I don't believe much would be sold if Your Honor please, but it's totally hypothetical.

context.speaker: Daniel B. Hodgson
context.text: There's a series of affidavits in the filing of this case that we got up with the FDIC, and went on and solicited all the shareholders and they all affirmed that they like it with C&S and they weren't interested in to selling and they know C&S management and they know the success of C&S in the State of Georgia.

context.text: For many years the State of Georgia restricted banks located in cities from opening branches in suburban areas.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1123, United States against Feola will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun along with 73-1452, Oregon against Hass.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: For the No. 1123, the Feola case is one that comes to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The respondent Feola and others were convicted in a jury trial violating a federal statute for having assaulted federal undercover narcotics agents in the performance of their official duties and of violating still another statute for conspiring to commit that offense.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: They were in civilian clothes and had been assumed by the respondent to be buyers rather than federal agents.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today we hold that knowledge of the identity of the victim is not necessary for a federal conviction for either the substantive charge or the conspiracy charge.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And the judgment of the Court of Appeals insofar as it concerns the conspiracy is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to say that Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion and is joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: They were in civilian clothes and had been assumed by the respondent to be buyers rather than federal agents.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today we hold that knowledge of the identity of the victim is not necessary for a federal conviction for either the substantive charge or the conspiracy charge.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And the judgment of the Court of Appeals insofar as it concerns the conspiracy is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I'm authorized to say that Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a dissenting opinion and is joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But the Government never sought to use that as evidence so far as this case is concerned, is that not correct?

context.speaker: Paul L. Friedman
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Paul L. Friedman
context.text: And so far as we know it was never charged for that.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And it would be reasonably assumed can it that someone concluded that that pistol fit precisely under what Mr. Justice White has just postulated namely, they had come into the possession of that pistol by invading the privacy of the driver's car?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well let's assume that -- let's assume police break into a man's house illegally without a warrant but knowing that a henchman of his is there, and they arrest the henchman.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They take him out of the house.

context.speaker: Joseph Beeler
context.text: Then after that, they demand some proof of identity.

context.speaker: Joseph Beeler
context.text: And when they carry on this kind of procedure, I think it's -- it's not in the record other than that Mr. Sanchez is a Mexican-American.

context.speaker: Joseph Beeler
context.text: But I --

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In your colloquy with Mr. Justice Stewart, reference was made to the search.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: What search do you have in mind?

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: What do you think constituted a search?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I have the disposition to announce in 73-820, United States against Guana-Sanchez in which the writ of certiorari is dismissed as having been improvidently granted.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the consideration or decision.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- made in the Griffin case.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: The jury by the instruction to limit this to credibility is really being told that they can consider the silence and that into infer that the defendant is lying on the stand when he says that he is innocent, but they can't consider his silence to infer guilt.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: I just don't think that the jury can really successfully engage in such mental gymnastics and understand that explanation completely.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, does it not as Mr. Justice Stewart just suggested involve some struggle on the part of the jury to listen perhaps for four or five days to witnesses testifying against the defendant and then never hear from the defendant?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Is there not somewhat the same kind of problem there?

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: Yes, there is.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: No, it isn't written into the Fifth Amendment.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: The Fifth Amendment said that no person shall be compelled to be a witness against himself in the criminal case.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: It seems to me that if his silence isn't brought out, even on impeachment, then he is being a witness himself in a criminal case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: So the police -- what you argued and the response for which the way you responded to Justice Rehnquist, all these matters could be brought out (a) by this redirect examination and (b) in the closing argument to the jury, the members of the jury presumably see as many television programs as your client does or other people do.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Isn't this sort of the same thing as evidence of flight which the general rule is admissible and which could be explained often?

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: These things could be brought out on rebuttal.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: Again here, we're talking about Mr. Hale at the police station where he has just been arrested.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: He does not have counsel present.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: There is no -- there should be no pressure on him to explain at that time to the police.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Of course, Mr. Justice Frankfurter's opinion to be sure it was a concurring opinion not an opinion of the court was to the effect that in the ordinary run of the generality of human experience, if people have an explanation, a valid explanation, they give it, and that therefore the failure to do what is found to be the generality of human experience is something a jury is entitled to hear about and consider.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would I take that you would reject Mr. Justice Frankfurter's view on the matter?

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: Yes, I would.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: He does not have counsel present.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: There is no -- there should be no pressure on him to explain at that time to the police.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Of course, Mr. Justice Frankfurter's opinion to be sure it was a concurring opinion not an opinion of the court was to the effect that in the ordinary run of the generality of human experience, if people have an explanation, a valid explanation, they give it, and that therefore the failure to do what is found to be the generality of human experience is something a jury is entitled to hear about and consider.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would I take that you would reject Mr. Justice Frankfurter's view on the matter?

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: Yes, I would.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: That view was expressed prior to the time to the no comment rule was held or did the Fifth Amendment, excuse me, was held applicable to the states in a state case and just -- would reject that view.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: No, it would not.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: I still don't think you would have to explain that at the police station.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Why?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: That isn't quite consistent with what at least I understood you told Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: The pressure to explain at trial by the presumption of that that exists when a person is found in possession of recently stolen property is a difference sort of pressure than the pressure at the police station that a defendant might feel to talk to the police.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I'm talking about the explanation at the same point in time.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: He later changed that to $96.00.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: There is a difference in the amount of the money.

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: There's no way to necessarily link that to the money that was actually taken.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Ritchie, in light of Justice Harlan's opinion in Grunewald, is it necessary for you to rely as strongly as you do on the Fifth Amendment?

context.speaker: Larry J. Ritchie
context.text: Well, I think it is for the reason that Grunewald was a case in which the court exercised their supervisory power over the lower federal courts.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It was not a constitutional decision.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 74-364, United States against will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Government sought reinstatement of respondent's conviction for robbery on the ground that since respondent chose to testify in his own behalf that it was permissible to impeach his credibility by providing that he had chosen to remain silent at the time of his arrest.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Additionally, we find no indication that the respondent's prior silence was so clearly inconsistent with his trial testimony as to warrant admission into evidence of his silence as a prior inconsistent statement.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In view of the strong potential for prejudice from admission of the evidence, a mistrial should have been granted.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Douglas, and Mr. Justice White have filed separate opinions concurring in the judgment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And Mr. Justice Blackmun has concurred in the result.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But Mr. Friedman, supposing I commit the offense of robbery and take $100 from you.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, you wouldn't say that each day I keep your $100 I am committing events of robbery, would you?

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: No, Mr. Justice, but I think that's a different situation, I think.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, and the court could require me to make restitution just as you in answer to Justice White said that divestiture can be regarded, even though robbery is a one time offense?

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: Yes, but the restitution it seems to me, that's a different thing.

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: That's to make hold the victim of the robbery, but here we are dealing with an order, which it seems to me, is not designed merely to protect one individual against the theft of his property.

United States v. ITT Continental Baking.speaker: Justice Burger
United States v. ITT Continental Baking.case_name: United States v. ITT Continental Baking Company
United States v. ITT Continental Baking.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 13, 1974

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: Here what we have, it is the agreement of the parties, the complaint can be referred to and also this Appendix which the Commission had before it in dealing, in deciding to adapt the order.

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: Secondly, all that was involved in Armour was the interpretation of the judgment.

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: In this case, we have to interpret the consent order in the light of the statute specifically dealing and providing penalties for continuing offenses and we think that the Armour case does not support the decision below.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Did I understand you correctly, in answer in response to Mr. Justice White, that this consent decree could have been made so clear and unambiguous that there wouldn't be any question to litigate?

context.speaker: Friedman
context.text: Well I --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Except the amount?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit affirmed the District Court's interpretation of the consent order as proscribing only the initial act of purchase and held that therefore only a single penalty might be imposed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that the word acquiring as used in the consent order means both the initial purchase and the maintaining of the rights acquired so that the violations are continuing violations subject to daily penalties.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart dissents and joined by the Chief Justice.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell and Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: James S. Carroll
context.text: I am saying that.

context.speaker: James S. Carroll
context.text: I am also stating that the distinction that the Government makes between a pure legal ruling and findings of fact is not articulated anywhere in the case law and in fact is directly contradicted by the case law.

context.speaker: James S. Carroll
context.text: Sisson makes it very clear that the rule of a test is to be used is whether on the basis of facts adduced at the trial going to the general issue of the case, whether the defendant is guilty or not guilty.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Carroll to pursue Mr. Justice Blackmun's question and to which you answer that there would be no way of avoiding a new trial.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would trial be limited to the eviction to have a bench trial or it would be parties all be freed, start from scratch as it were if you decide to have a jury trial they wanted.

context.speaker: James S. Carroll
context.text: I imagine that parties would start from scratch, but the first motion that would be made in such a case would be a motion in bar to stop such a trial on the grounds of Double Jeopardy, but I do not think that it is necessary to go that far because I think the appeal in this case alone puts the defendant in Double Jeopardy.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-1513, United States against Jenkins will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It involves a construction of the Double Jeopardy Clause of the constitution.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Unlike Wilson, there is no guilty verdict or finding of guilt which could simply be reinstated in the event an Appellate Court reversed on a legal error.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Since additional proceedings devoted to resolution of factual issues going to the elements of the offense charged would be required upon reversal and remand to subject respondent any further proceedings would violate the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We accordingly affirm the judgment of the Second Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joins has filed a concurring statement.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Charles E. Hamilton
context.text: But the Shoshone and Arapahoe tribes and I had considerable problems practicing law up there over the past years in trying to go to the tribal council with people that I felt in my opinion were qualified to be enrolled and have them summarily dismiss me and say, We dont want to listen to you Mr. Hamilton and of course, theres no appeal, of course.

context.speaker: Charles E. Hamilton
context.text: And so, these people were not enrolled.

context.speaker: Charles E. Hamilton
context.text: And its kind of a -- its kind of a personality thing up there and its a very difficult thing to deal with.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Could your client have come within any of the possible definitions of 1154 (c) that you mentioned a moment ago before Justice Douglas asked you the question?

context.speaker: Charles E. Hamilton
context.text: So far as the criteria for admittance into the club, no sir.

context.speaker: Charles E. Hamilton
context.text: He would not.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion in 73-1018, in Mazurie -- United States against Mazurie will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In this case the respondents are non-Indians who are prosecuted for operating a bar on private land within an Indian reservation without having obtained a tribal permit which is required by federal law.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit reversed their convictions on the grounds that the statute defining the offense was so vague that its enforcement would violate due process.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Rather, our cases have said that they are unique entities which possess attributes of sovereignty and are historically empowered to exercise authority over matters relating to their internal order and relations.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Under these cases, these facts are sufficient to protect Congress' decision that they should be empowered to control the sale of alcoholic beverages on their reservation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
