context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Finally, we conclude that the alleged horizontal restrictions on the marketing and mutual-fund shares are immunized by pervasive regulatory schemes of the Maloney and Investment Company Acts.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The activities here challenged are related to and are supportive of those immunized by Section 22 (f) of the Investment Company Act.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Subjecting them to antitrust liability would lead to possibly inconsistent and conflicting judgments between the courts and the SEC that would limit the Commissions' flexible mandate to regulate the mutual-fund industry.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Where was your primary obligation?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.text: But what the Trial Court judge ordered in petitioner's view point and I think it's the reasonable interpretation, was that all relevant material be turned over.

context.speaker: Nicholas R. Allis
context.text: Now the way that's done, this Court said in Hickman is with a certain degree of privacy.

context.speaker: Nicholas R. Allis
context.text: This is --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: There's a lot of District Court law that says that statements for investigators are not protected under Hickman.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case involves the criminal conviction of the respondent, John R. Park for violating the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetics Act.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Court of Appeals reversed the judgment of conviction finding that as instructed by the trial judge, the members of the jury were given no objective standards by which to determine whether Park was guilty or innocent and indeed that the jury were allowed to convict Park even if they found no wrongdoing on his part of any kind.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Today the Court reverses the Court of Appeals and reinstates Park's conviction.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell and I, agree with the Court of Appeals that this criminal conviction was totally invalid.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The instructions given by the trial judge in this case were a virtual nullity, a mere authorization to convict if the jury thought it appropriate to do so.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Instructions of -- like that regardless of the blame worthiness of the defendant's conduct, regardless of the social value of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, and regardless of the importance of convicting those who violate that Act have no place in our jurisprudence.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: So the standardless conviction approved today can serve in another case tomorrow to support a felony conviction and a substantial prison sentence however highly the Court may regard the social objectives of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetics Act, that regard cannot serve to justify a criminal conviction so wholly alien to fundamental principles of our law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Before a person can be convicted of a criminal violation of this Act, a jury must find, and must be clearly instructed that it must find, evidence beyond a reasonable doubt that he engaged in wrongful conduct amounting at least to common-law negligence.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: There were no such instructions, and clearly, therefore, no such finding in this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in more detail in a written opinion filed with the clerk today, Mr. Justice Marshall, Mr. Justice Powell, and I, respectfully dissent from the opinion and judgment of the Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

context.speaker: William L. Patton, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Doesn't it come down with the proposition that you're saying that the officer should have known and been able to predict the ultimate outcome of the Almeida-Sanchez case?

context.speaker: Sandor W. Shapery
context.text: I don't think that's the case.

context.speaker: Sandor W. Shapery
context.text: I think--

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In terms of the deterrence that Mr. Justice Powell was asking you about.

context.speaker: Sandor W. Shapery
context.text: I think the point should not have been left up to the individual officer as such.

context.speaker: Sandor W. Shapery
context.text: I think that the problem stems from his superiors, from the attorneys working in passing-- in creating these rules and regulations pursuant to the statute, and I feel that they, at all times, realize that they were rather in a precarious position.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 73-2000, United States against Peltier will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The respondent in this case was convicted of the possession of marihuana which was seized by Border Patrol agents during a search of his car 70 miles from the Mexican border.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed the conviction on the grounds that this Court's decision in Almeida-Sanchez against United States two terms ago, which issued four months after the search of the respondent's car should be applied to suppress the 270 pounds of marihuana found by Border Patrol agents.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Searches of the variety involved in this case were authorized by statute and regulation and were continuously approved by Circuit Courts until this Court's decision in Almeida-Sanchez.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The deterrence objectives of the exclusionary rule would not be furthered by suppression of the evidence involved in this case nor were the imperatives of judicial integrity offended by the use of this evidence in respondent's trial.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore, reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan joined by Mr. Justice Marshall and by Mr. Justice Stewart in Part I of that opinion has also filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The deterrence objectives of the exclusionary rule would not be furthered by suppression of the evidence involved in this case nor were the imperatives of judicial integrity offended by the use of this evidence in respondent's trial.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore, reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan joined by Mr. Justice Marshall and by Mr. Justice Stewart in Part I of that opinion has also filed a dissenting opinion.

United States v. Reliable Transfer Compa.speaker: Justice Burger
United States v. Reliable Transfer Compa.case_name: United States v. Reliable Transfer Company, Inc.
United States v. Reliable Transfer Compa.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 19, 1975

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We granted certiorari in this case to decide whether this countrys admiralty rule of divided damages should be replaced by a rule requiring when possible the allocation of liability for damages in proportion to the relative fault of each party.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reason set out in detail in the written opinion of the Court, we hold that when two or more parties have contributed by their fault to cause property damage in a maritime collision or stranding, liability for such damage is to allocated among the parties proportionately to the comparative degree of their fault and that liability for such damages is to be allocated equally only when the parties are equally at fault or when it is not possible fairly to measure the comparative degree of their fault.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment before us is vacated and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with the opinion of the Court filed today.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.case_name: United States v. Tax Commission of Mississippi
United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 22, 1975

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: All Im suggesting is there are certain kinds which the state does not stock.

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: And in that sense, the option is a convenience to them because they can then not go through the slower process of going ordering especially through the state.

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: They can go directly to the distiller, order it from him, but in that case of course, the tax will be collected from the distiller.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Wright, suppose taking the hypothetical case that Mr. Justice Powell suggested, suppose the state did that and then the response of the United States was that they would load a hundred trucks with all the supplies they needed including replacement shoes and ammunition and peanut butter and what not along with vodka and whiskey and gin, and shipped the whole thing in, do you suggest that Mississippi could stop that shipment and stop liquor from coming into a military base?

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: If they found out about it, theres no --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Im assuming it.

United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.speaker: Justice Burger
United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.case_name: United States v. Tax Commission of Mississippi
United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 22, 1975

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: But I --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Thats 107, isnt it?

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: Yes, thats 107.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Then, how do you reconcile that with your answer to Mr. Justice Marshall when you said that they couldnt levy a tax on the sales made in the officers club?

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: Well, the sales made in the officers club are not of issue here, because we do have a regulation which exempts the military clubs.

context.speaker: Robert L. Wright
context.text: This is the same regulation they complain about.

United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.speaker: Justice Brennan
United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.case_name: United States v. Tax Commission of Mississippi
United States v. Tax Commission of Missi.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 02, 1975

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: A three-judge District Court for the Southern District of Mississippi held that the legal incidence of the tax is upon the out-state-liquor dealers and suppliers and therefore rejected the argument of the United States that the tax is unconstitutional under the doctrine of McCulloch and Maryland as a state upon instrumentalities of the United States.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that since Mississippi law requires that the out-of-state sellers collect the tax from the military, the legal incidence of the tax as a matter of law is upon the military and therefore that the tax is an unconstitutional state levy upon instrumentalities of the United States.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Rehnquist dissents and have filed a dissenting statement.

context.speaker: Sheila Ginsberg
context.text: Well, that may well be, Your Honor, but I think that, as a general principle of law and as it applies in this case, a Rule 35 motion is insufficient to compensate for the deficiencies of this procedure.

context.speaker: Sheila Ginsberg
context.text: Firstly, a Rule 35 motion does not go to the imposition of the criminal conviction and secondly, I think that what that procedure countenance is, is the imposition of a final sentence based on inadequate information.

context.speaker: Sheila Ginsberg
context.text: It places the respondent in a position of coming into Court and convincing the judge that his initial decision was incorrect.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, I could understand your position about his possible mental condition if he had engaged in disruptive conduct as in the case that Mr. Justice Stewart referred to.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Here, he was casting his refusal on strictly legal grounds, was he not and there was no disruption of the courtroom?

context.speaker: Sheila Ginsberg
context.text: Oh!

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: The only difference between the substitute parent rule in King versus Smith, and the New York lodger rule, is that whereas Alabama completely denied AFDC children -- AFDC assistance.

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: The New York rule works a reduction in the AFDC grant because the caretaker relative has chosen to allow another person to reside in the home.

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: We submit that this Court in King versus Smith did not imply, and we submit did not intend that needy and dependent children can be denied part of their AFDC assistance based upon the fiction that their needs have diminished because the caretaker relative associates with the person who has the same characteristics as the substitute parent in King versus Smith.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But on the other hand, in Mr. Justice Rehnquist's example, mother and children are occupying two bedrooms and the mother's sister moves in with them and the children move in with the mother and the sister occupies the other bedroom.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I suppose the children aren't really enjoying the space they used to enjoy?

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: I think that if New York had a rule that was based upon an assessment of the space needed for the family, and if in fact --

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: It seems to me that that is only going to cause further harm to the family.

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: It's not a means of tackling the problem.

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: Our claim under the --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, you really come back to what Mr. Justice White suggested that all they can do is -- the state can do is initiate a proceeding to take the children away from the mother?

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: Well as I say, there are steps prior to that drastic steps that possibility of case work services is there.

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: There are immediate -- intermediate steps that --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Do you suggest the state would be enabled to bring an eviction proceeding against the lodger?

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: Well, the state would have no standing under New York state law to bring an eviction proceeding.

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: Only the --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What if these mediation efforts that Mr. Justice White was asking you about failed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What is the ultimate --

context.speaker: Martin A. Schwartz
context.text: Well as I say, if they fail, the Department of Social Services may well have to bring in neglect proceeding.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In No. 74-453, a three-judge District Court in the Southern District of New York held that the New York regulation was unconstitutional because in violation of the Due Process Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In light of our decision in 74-5054, we have no occasion to address that or any constitutional question.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we vacate the judgment of the three-judge court and remand with direction to dismiss the case to that extent as moot.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: 74-5054 and 74-453, are concerned with a New York regulation under which the rent allowance payable to a recipient of aid under the program of Aid to Families with Dependent Children is reduced when the recipient takes a non-paying lodger into the home.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In No. 74-5054, the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held that this New York regulation does not conflict with the Federal Social Security Act and the regulations under that statute.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree and reverse.

context.text: Following up the questions that were asked you by Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Blackmun, I understood you to say that maintenance and cure did not last for life under any circumstances.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 73-1994, Vella against Ford Motor Company will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here from the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The question is whether a shipowner's duty to furnish maintenance and cure to a seaman who suffers an incurable injury aboard ship continues from the date the seaman leaves the ship to the date when a medical diagnosis is made that his injury was in fact incurable when he left the ship.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The question is whether a shipowner's duty to furnish maintenance and cure to a seaman who suffers an incurable injury aboard ship continues from the date the seaman leaves the ship to the date when a medical diagnosis is made that his injury was in fact incurable when he left the ship.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit held that the shipowner's duty did not continue after but terminated when the seaman left the ship.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We unanimously reverse.

context.text: We do not believe that other than marriage, there is a special relationship.

context.text: However, that would not distinguish this case from Vlandis or United States Department of Agriculture versus Murry or Heiner versus Donnan or Schlesinger versus Wisconsin, all of them concludes presumption cases without any special relationship.

context.text: I take it in your answer to Justice White, you're really reaching for unattainable perfection, aren't you?

context.text: No Your Honor.

context.speaker: Don B. Kates, Jr.
context.text: All that we seek in terms of the Equal Protection Clause -- in terms of the conclusive presumption matter, we believe that a -- that as this Court has repeatedly held, a person is entitled to prove the facts of his or her entitlement and that Congress may not arbitrarily decide that an evidentiary conclusive presumption -- a presumption in this case of a falsehood can be substituted for the person's right to prove the actual facts.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in No. 74-214, Weinberger against Salfi will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Social Security Act provides benefits for minor children of deceased wage earners and for mothers of such children who have them in their care.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Act defines eligible children and mothers in such a way that a wage earner's stepchildren and their mother are eligible only if the mother's marriage to the wage earner and the child's relationship as a stepchild of the wage earner had existed for at least nine months before the wage earner's death.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: While the requirement does not necessarily exclude all claimants who entered such sham relationships and plainly does not exclude -- does exclude some persons whose good faith marriages were terminated by an unexpected death.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It was nonetheless not unreasonable for Congress to conclude that the requirements inherent imprecision was justified by its clarity and ease of administration.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the District Court is therefore reversed.

context.text: However, when a covered female worker dies, leaving a husband and minor children, survivors' benefits are paid only to the children and not to the widower.

context.text: I have the judgment and opinion of the Court to announce in No. 73-1462, White against Regester.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: A statute of the State of Wisconsin empowers a State Examining Board to license physicians and to investigate charges of professional misconduct and to revoke and suspend licenses.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: When proceedings were instituted against appellee, he resorted to the federal court and brought this suit.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The state appealed and for the reasons we given in the opinion at some length, we unanimously reverse.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In our view, appellee is not likely to succeed on the constitutional grounds he alleged combining investigative and adjudicating functions is not per se unconstitutional and it is not unconstitutional in the circumstances of this case.
